"We appreciate and respect all peaceful protests, but it is now time for people to go home." California governor declares state of emergency in LA County Los Angeles Mayor Eric Garcetti requested assistance to restore order Saturday night amid protests. A curfew began at 8 p.m. PT and is expected to end at 5:30 a.m. local time. The LAPD said hundreds of protesters were arrested amid the protests. An unlawful assembly was declared in the the Mid-Wilshire area and businesses were asked to close. Protesters blocked the 110 freeway in downtown LA and videos taken at protests showed looting and broken windows at stores in The Grove mall. Garcetti urged protesters to "take a breath" and "step away" at a press conference. He asked residents to go home and protest peacefully at a later time. We will always protect free speech and Angelenos’ right to live without fear of violence or vandalism. To increase safety for demonstrators, law enforcement and all citizens of Los Angeles, we are putting a curfew in place from 8 p.m. to 5 a.m. https://t.co/vy3XM760qb — MayorOfLA (@MayorOfLA) May 30, 2020 Gov. Gavin Newsom announced the National Guard would be deployed to Los Angeles and proclaimed a state of emergency in Los Angeles County. Governor Newsom has authorized assistance after a request from @LACity and @CountyofLA, and proclaimed a state of emergency in Los Angeles County. https://t.co/pAhSQtBxD1 — Office of the Governor of California (@CAgovernor) May 31, 2020 Tense standoffs outside White House In Washington, National Guard troops were called in Saturday night to assist police and Secret Service officers in blocking off the White House after a day of confrontations between law enforcement and protesters. Demonstrators flocked to the White House and nearby Lafayette Square throughout the afternoon where city and U.S. Park police and the Secret Service maintained barricades and pushed back against protesters, at times using pepper spray in an attempt to disperse crowds. Fireworks were set off and at least one car was set on fire. Buildings in downtown Washington had windows smashed — including the Ronald Reagan Presidential Foundation and Institute and an Apple store. A liquor store and a T-Mobile were also looted as tensions remained high through the early morning. The D.C. police union tweeted that one of its members had been hospitalized after being hit by a rock. We can confirm that at least one member has been hospitalized after being struck with a rock. — DC Police Union (@DCPoliceUnion) May 31, 2020 Earlier on Saturday, President Trump falsely accused the city's mayor, Muriel Bowser, of refusing to let D.C. police assist in containing Friday night's demonstrations. Bowser fired back at Trump at a Saturday press conference, saying the president's warning that "ominous weapons" and "vicious dogs" awaited any protester who made it past the White House fence was "no subtle reminder" of the country's history of segregationist violence. On Sunday morning, Bowser reiterated that sentiment on NBC's Meet The Press. "I think the president has a responsibility to help calm the nation and he can start by not sending divisive tweets that are meant to harken to the segregationist past of our country and he can start by doing that right now," Bowser said. This is a developing story. Some things reported by the media will turn out to be wrong. We will focus on reports from officials and other authorities, credible news outlets and reporters who are at the scene. We will update as the situation develops.

title: Lawmakers react to the protests across Tennessee after the death of George Floyd
text: TENNESSEE (WATE) – So far, protests in reaction to the death of George Floyd in Minnesota have occurred all across Tennessee. There have been protests and rallies in Knoxville, Morristown, Nashville and Memphis after a video of Floyd’s death also sparked protests all across the country. RELATED: Protests emerge across Tennessee after the death of George Floyd in Minnesota In Middle Tennessee, Governor Bill Lee mobilized the National Guard in Nashville as violence erupted during a protest late Saturday night. FILE – (AP Photo/Mark Humphrey, File) “At the request of Mayor Cooper, I am authorizing the National Guard to mobilize in response to protests that have now taken a violent, unlawful turn in Nashville. The threat to both peace and property is unacceptable and we will work with local law enforcement and community leaders to restore safety and order. This is not a reflection of our state or the fundamental American right to peaceful protest.” Governor Bill Lee FILE – State Sen. Randy McNally, R-Oak Ridge. Lieutenant Governor Randy McNally took to Twitter and said, “What is happening in Nashville is a descent into madness. This is not who we are. The outside agitators responsible for this mayhem should cease, desist and leave our state. The police are not perfect. Those who transgress against our citizens should be brought to justice.” McNally continued to say that law enforcement is the only thing keeping order amid the chaos, and that he supported Gov. Lee’s decision to mobilize the National Guard and the THP Strike Force. “This lawlessness is counterproductive and wrong. It needs to end tonight.” Lt. Governor Randy McNally Representative Chuck Fleischmann says that his heart breaks after seeing initially peaceful protests turn violent. Rep. Chuck Fleischmann ”Protestors who are peacefully exercising their first amendment right should be allowed to be heard.‪ Chief Deputy Austin Garrett, Chief David Roddy, Chattanooga Police Department, Hamilton County Sheriffs Office have shown incredible leadership.‪ I also want to applaud the work of our local journalists who are continuing to work around the clock to ensure our community stays informed WRCB Channel 3 Eyewitness News, News 12 Now, WTVC-TV News, Channel 9 News, Chattanooga Times Free Press, Knoxville News Sentinel, WATE 6 On Your Side, WVLT, and WBIR Channel 10‪. It has been a rough year, and our nation will not heal overnight, but we should not forget how blessed we all are to live in the world’s strongest republic.‪ I know there are brighter days ahead if we remember that we are all united as one nation under God.” Rep. Chuck Fleischmann Representative Tim Burchett also released a statement regarding the violence in Nashville and nationwide. Tim Burchett. (Photo: WATE) “The killing of George Floyd was tragic, unnecessary and unacceptable. Communities of color, and in fact our entire nation, are right to be angry, and protesting peacefully and lawfully is an appropriate way to express that anger. Rioting, as we’ve seen across our country in recent days and in Nashville tonight is illegal and unworthy of being called a protest or a rally. Looting and damaging businesses, destroying private property, vandalizing and burning public buildings are acts that distract from the memory of George Floyd and the ongoing effort to eliminate racism in our country. Thankfully, in my hometown of Knoxville, protests yesterday were peaceful. Rather than uncontrolled opportunistic violence and looting, our country need to come together in unity and in prayer.” Rep. Tim Burchett At around 9:04 p.m. Saturday, Representative Jason Zachary took to Twitter, thanking law enforcement for the job they’re doing in Nashville. “Our @TNHighwayPatrol are risking their lives to protect our State Capitol from the criminals and vandals who are trashing Nashville. Please join me in praying for these men and women. I’m with them every week and they are true public servants.” Rep. Jason Zachary Our @TNHighwayPatrol are risking their lives to protect our State Capitol from the criminals and vandals who are trashing Nashville. Please join me in praying for these men and women. I’m with them every week and they are true public servants. pic.twitter.com/33WuHl5AhY — Rep. Jason Zachary (@JasonZacharyTN) May 31, 2020 University of Tennessee Athletics releases ‘unified statement’ The University of Tennessee Athletic Director Phillip Fulmer, along with 15 of the university’s head coaches released a unified statement: “We hold our student-athletes to very high standards. With rare exceptions, our young men and women meet those standards and represent themselves, their families, their teams and the University of Tennessee with excellence—academically, athletically and socially. Right now, our student-athletes are hurting. They navigate an emotional road of sadness, confusion and rage. Our black student-athletes carry the added burden of fear and hopelessness—an old wound torn open again by the horrifying, auto-repeat playlist of viral violence in our country that seemingly will not cease. As Tennessee head coaches, we are now calling on anyone who is a fan of the Vols and Lady Vols to meet and expect a standard in our daily walk. Let us all refuse to accept or tolerate the unjust treatment of our black neighbors. Let us challenge those who attempt to justify, dismiss, ignore or explain away mistreatment of blacks or any other person of color. Let us meet this standard head-on, out loud and outside our homes. Demand action that leads to change. Demand PROGRESS. This is a basic, human principle that, among some, seems to have become as endangered as basic human rights for blacks in our communities. Society could benefit by injecting into our communities an element of the “team” mindset that exists in a sport locker room. It’s widely accepted that sport teaches valuable lessons about leadership, discipline, collaboration, dependability and perseverance. However, the most IMPACTFUL and life-changing lesson sport teaches might actually be the lesser-touted ability to fully accept and embrace people who are different from us and have very different life experiences. On healthy teams, if you wear the same jersey as me, I’ve got your back—regardless of race or ethnicity, it doesn’t matter. Let’s go work together and win. Period. Wherever you’re reading this, it likely holds true that the cultures that exist in the sports programs at your local high school or college are much healthier than the culture in your local community. Why do these healthy cultures exist in small sports teams’ locker rooms all across the country, but not in our larger communities? What can we study within a healthy team dynamic that can be applied to a metropolitan city or a rural farm town? As coaches, we don’t have all the answers to fix what’s been broken for so long. But if total acceptance, understanding and empathy—regardless of human differences—can coexist on sports teams, those things should be able to coexist anywhere. Vol Nation, let’s rise to the challenge to meet a new standard. If you’re going to support our black student-athletes when they compete, please have the courage to support them and their families in their daily pursuit of peace, happiness and equity.” Phillip Fulmer , Director of Athletics Beth Alford-Sullivan , Track & Field/Cross Country Rick Barnes , Men’s Basketball Lisa Glenn , Rowing Kellie Harper , Women’s Basketball Matt Kredich , Swimming & Diving Alison Ojeda , Women’s Tennis Judi Pavon , Women’s Golf Brian Pensky , Soccer Jeremy Pruitt , Football Eve Rackham , Volleyball Tony Vitello , Baseball Brennan Webb , Men’s Golf Karen Weekly , Softball Ralph Weekly , Softball Chris Woodruff , Men’s Tennis LATEST STORIES:

title: Store owners, neighbors clean up downtown Nashville after vandalism
text: CLOSE Joe Britton stepped past pieces of shattered glass to give Christopher Hugo a hug. Hugo looked into his Sbarro Pizza on the corner of Second Avenue and Commerce Street. The corridor was one of the hardest hit by vandals after a peaceful demonstration in response to the death of George Floyd, an unarmed black man who died after being pinned down by a white Minneapolis police officer. A march following the "I Will Breathe" rally to protest police brutality in Nashville turned destructive Saturday evening. Businesses, government buildings and a police cruiser were damaged. Crews put up boards over broken windows at Sbarro Pizza in downtown Nashville on Sunday, May 31, 2020. (Photo: Shelley Mays / The Tennessean) "We saw it happening on the news, and thought, 'no — please no,'" said Hugo, who owns the restaurant. "I don't know why they are doing this. It turned violent, and all it takes is a spark." Britton walked away from Hugo to let him clean up the location, where televisions were destroyed and windows were smashed. Someone had attempted to steal the cash register. Britton moved to Nashville 16 months ago and became friends with the pizza shop owners. On Saturday night, he and other tenants stood in front of their apartment building in hopes of impeding any vandalism to their homes. "They were friendly toward people, but not toward businesses," he said. "They had sledgehammers. They had evil in their eyes. But this isn't about me. It's about the business owners who are dealing with this today." Down the street on Second Avenue, Johanna Harlan swept glass off the floor of Honey Girl, a fashion boutique that's been in downtown for seven years. Harlan said merchandise had been taken and the showroom floor was destroyed. Honey Girl owner Johanna Harlan talks about the damage and looting to her store Sunday, May 31, 2020, the morning after violence in Nashville following a rally in protest of the death of George Floyd, an unarmed black man who died after being pinned down by a Minneapolis police officer. (Photo: Shelley Mays / The Tennessean) "Honestly, last night was the worst," she said. "I found about it when I saw the video someone sent. I am more positive this morning, but it is still sad. They took a lot. It makes me think: Violence leads to more violence." On Broadway, crews were boarding up damaged honky-tonks and washing away the graffiti on Bridgestone Arena. Volunteers armed with water and Krud Kutter cleaner also removed graffiti written all over the side of the building. Patrick McKenon volunteers to remove graffiti off the Bridgestone Arena wall Sunday, May 31, 2020. (Photo: Shelley Mays / The Tennessean) "I put on Facebook I was going to do this after I went to Home Depot, and I hope other people come," Nashville native and volunteer Patrick McKenon said. "All of a sudden, things unraveled and escalated last night. I feel for all these businesses. I am here because I wanted to take our city back." Emily West is a reporter for The Tennessean. Follow her on Twitter at emwest22 or email her at erwest@tennessean.com. Read or Share this story: https://www.tennessean.com/story/news/2020/05/31/downtown-damage-clean-up-nashville-protest/5299391002/

title: Nashville endures decimation, isolation — and now, a peaceful uprising turned destructive
text: The historic courthouse burned, flames swelling through the first-floor windows. Clouds of tear gas mushroomed across Public Square Park. Windows shattered, and spray paint tagged the walls. As conflict and destruction erupted in the aftermath of a peaceful protest in Nashville on Saturday, it left a mark on a city already scarred. The decimation of deadly tornadoes. The forced isolation of a pandemic. A peaceful rise against injustice overtaken by vandals. Nashville has endured the unimaginable this year. On Saturday afternoon, protesters streamed through Nashville's streets toward the courthouse as part of the "I Will Breathe" rally to decry police brutality and the killing of George Floyd in Minneapolis and other black men and women across the country. The scene of Nashville's protest reflected images of 60 years ago, when thousands marched silently to the courthouse steps as part of Nashville's sit-in movement. That nonviolent uprising led to the integration of Nashville's lunch counters, a historic moment in the city's history. This time, near dusk on Saturday, tensions flared. At least 30 Nashville businesses were damaged. The Metro Nashville Police Department arrested 28 people during the protests or after the 10 p.m. curfew. Eleven of those people were white, 16 black and one Hispanic. Seven of the arrestswere made after midnight on Broadway downtown. Early Sunday morning, the scream of security alarms stillechoed on empty downtown streets, highlighting the trauma. The name George Floyd emblazoned the wall of Bridgestone Arena, written in yellow spray paint. Windows lay in shards at the historic Ryman Auditorium and dozens of stores and famous honky tonks along the city's tourism corridor. The cash register terminal and sound equipment were smashed at The Stage, where the staff had fortified in a back office for protection. The smoldering flames singed the air from a fire at Boot Barn a few doors down. At the courthouse, graffiti marked the building's limestone facade. The letters BLM, for Black Lives Matter, tagged the towering doors. The words "sleep now in fire" marred a corner of the building. On the entry columns, the phrase "F--- 12" was scrawled in black spray paint, a slang term used repeatedly during ongoing protests and riots. The "12" standing for L, the 12th letter in the alphabet, and for the word "law." And the granite plaque commemorating Diane Nash, a civil rights leader in Nashville, was broken to pieces — its fragments used to shatter windows. Nashville Fire Department investigators worked to determine who started the multiple fires downtown. Nashville police arrested a 25-year-old man on felony arson and vandalism charges Sunday night. An 8 p.m. curfew was put in place after Mayor John Cooper, declared a state of emergency. The order came, even as more rallies, including one in Murfreesboro on Sunday, prepared to begin. “It is our firm belief that those individuals defacing and destroying public property after the rally were not a part of the original event," The Equity Alliance co-founders and co-Executive Directors Charlane Oliver and Tequila Johnson said in a statement. "The actions by this small group reflect neither the beliefs of the groups that led today's peaceful assembly nor those of the majority of the attendees. This behavior dishonors the memory of George Floyd and other black Americans that have died unjustly at the hands of police. “The Equity Alliance condemns and disavows tonight’s violent rioting. We urge anyone feeling heartfelt, honest anger over the murder of George Floyd to direct that energy toward November’s election. The only true way to change our nation for the better is by taking up our civic duty as Americans and making it clear with our vote that we reject racism in all its forms.” A critical time to speak 'against senseless killing' Before Nashville's rally, many in the city stood together. Earlier in the week, Nashville Police Chief Steve Anderson, filled with disdain and "emotionally shaken," condemned the police behavior in Minneapolis. Cooper urged his fellow city leaders in the Metro Council to join him at the "I Will Breathe" rally. "This is an especially critical time for all of us, as Metro’s leaders, to show up and listen to Black voices speaking out from across Davidson County," he said, "as they speak out against the senseless killing of George Floyd and the deep-seated issues of racial injustice in our country." Thousands gathered without incident on a crowded Legislative Plaza at 3 p.m. Saturday. As speakers stepped up to a megaphone, the throngs cheered and chanted "I can’t breathe!" and "No justice, no peace!" Police stood on the outskirts of the rally directing traffic and didn’t interact with the demonstrators. About 4:40 p.m., protesters began marching downtown on Charlotte Avenue, with organizers urging participants to remain peaceful. Problems then began to emerge. A little more than a mile from the Capitol, several people were arrested when windows were smashed in a Metro Nashville police cruiser near Sixth Avenue South and Korean Veterans Boulevard. Some protesters later threw rocks and bottles at officers. Tensions ratcheted up as evening set in, and protesters started a fire at the Metro Nashville Courthouse. A short time later, police with riot gear arrived as flames licked the inside of City Hall. Officers deployed tear gas at people clustered in the center of Public Square Park. Nashville police issued a 10 p.m. curfew in the city on Saturday night. Cooper declared a state of civil emergency, and Gov. Bill Lee deployed the National Guard. "The threat to both peace and property is unacceptable and we will work with local law enforcement and community leaders to restore safety and order. This is not a reflection of our state or the fundamental American right to peaceful protest," Lee wrote on Twitter. Citizens come together to clean up: 'That's not who we are' Early Sunday, police stood in front of a chain-link fence outside of the Metro Nashville Courthouse to allow a city crew to clean up. Store owners assessed what had been broken or stolen — mobile phones, tourist trinkets, boots, a drum kit and more. Butch Spyridon, president of Nashville Convention and Visitors Corp., said it was too early to assess the extend of the damage, but he estimated it could be hundreds of thousands of dollars based on what he watched unfold on television "I'm without question at a loss for words, stunned by what I saw, and sad for Nashville," he said, "because that's not who we are." In the aftermath, the city's spirit emerged. Before daybreak, a construction worker boarded up windows without being asked. City preachers spoke about the rally and about violence against black people. The Rev. John Faison Sr. wrapped up Watson Grove Missionary Baptist Church’s morning worship service with a discussion about the purpose of protests. He was joined by local activist Justin Jones and Metro Councilperson Delishia Porterfield. "It’s designed to create tension," Jones said. "A protest with permission is a parade. A protest is not meant to be comfortable." The words echoed even as Nashville citizens and law enforcement came together with spray bottles and rags, volunteering to remove the graffiti on the side of Bridgestone Arena downtown. Carmen Turks, who works with the Davidson County Sheriff’s Department, volunteers to remove graffiti off the Bridgestone Arena wall Sunday, May 31, 2020, the morning after violence hit Nashville following a rally in protest of the death of George Floyd, an unarmed black man who died after being pinned down by a white Minneapolis police officer. (Photo: Shelley Mays / The Tennessean) "I think my emotions are the same as everyone who loves the city," said Sean Henry, president and CEO of the Predators. "You understand the anger and passions that are out there, because far too often we see examples of extreme racism boiling up. "In this case, a peaceful protest turned to violence, and we understand that underlying anger is there. There are many emotions involved — rightful emotions by the way — and we hope be part of the conversation to bring people together short term and long term. "We have this wonderful history of coming through things differently than other cities," Henry added. "And we do it together. I think that spirit will come through again." Reporters Natalie Allison, Natalie Alund, Shelley Mays, Holly Meyer, Cassandra Stephenson and Emily West contributed to this report. Reach Jessica Bliss at 615-259-8253 and jbliss@tennessean.com or on Twitter @jlbliss and please support local journalism. Read or Share this story: https://www.tennessean.com/story/news/2020/05/31/nashville-george-floyd-protests-unrest/5299058002/

title: 75 National Guardsmen were deployed Saturday in Nashville during protests
text: Faced with the possibility of additional violence, Gov. Bill Lee said Sunday he is increasing a deployment of the Tennessee National Guard to help with law enforcement, this time in all three divisions of the state. The governor made the announcement one day after 75 guardsmen were deployed in Nashville in response to an eruption of violence. The rancor occurred after a peaceful rally attended by thousands of Tennesseans who were protesting police brutality and racism. The governor did not say how many and exactly where the guardsmen will be deployed Sunday. Additionally, Lee announced a joint effort between the Tennessee Bureau of Investigation and local law enforcement to investigate Saturday's violence in Nashville, which he said was provoked by many non-Tennesseans. “The right to peaceful protest is foundational to our country, but the violence and vandalism that occurred in Nashville last night was unlawful and tears at the fabric of our community,” Lee said in a statement. “We have reason to believe that many of those involved in unlawful acts are not Tennesseans and we will be working with law enforcement to investigate this further and bring those responsible to justice.” The violence occurred hours after thousands of people gathered near the Capitol for a peaceful rally, following the death of George Floyd in Minneapolis. Organizers of Saturday's rally urged participants to remain peaceful but violence later erupted throughout the city's downtown area, including windows being smashed and a fire being set at the city's historic Metro Courthouse, which includes city hall offices. In total, 28 Metro Nashville police arrested 28 people Saturday night, many after the 10 p.m. curfew. Of those, 21 are from Nashville, four from elsewhere in Tennessee and three from out of state: Texas, Illinois and New York. Saturday's deployment of the National Guard, which was aimed at providing assistance to the Tennessee Highway Patrol and Metro Police Department, was likely the first such move for law enforcement purposes in decades. The guardsmen first reported to the Capitol grounds, where a statue was toppled over. The troops later moved to Lower Broadway, to provide assistance after businesses were damaged. Metro Nashville Police and protesters scuffle outside Central Precint in Nashville, Tenn., Saturday, May 30, 2020 after the “I Will Breathe” rally to protest the death of George Floyd, an unarmed black man who died after being pinned down by a white Minneapolis police officer on Memorial Day. (Photo: Andrew Nelles / The Tennessean) David Roberson, a spokesman for the Department of General Services, said the extent of damage to state-owned property included graffiti and broken windows and doors. Roberson said windows were broken at the War Memorial building, the Rachel Jackson and Andrew Jackson buildings and Citizens Plaza, where graffiti was also found. A door was broken at the state Supreme Court. Graffiti was found on the Capitol grounds, including on a wall. The toppled statue was to be removed Sunday. Roberson said there are no estimates of the total cost of the various damage to state-owned properties. Lee's deployment of the National Guard came at the request of Nashville Mayor John Cooper, said Laine Arnold, the governor's spokeswoman. The governor made the announcement shortly after 9 p.m. Lee signed an executive order, effectively affirming a 10 p.m. curfew Cooper implemented. "I mobilized the National Guard to assist in protecting the lives and property of Tennesseans, which is a critical responsibility of government," the governor's executive order stated. The governor signed another executive order on Sunday to once again coincide with Nashville's latest curfew, which is set for 8 p.m. Tennessee's last major deployment of its National Guard for law enforcement purposes occurred in 1968, after the assassination of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. As many as 4,000 guardsmen were deployed in Nashville the day King was murdered, according to The Tennessean's archives. Troops were stationed throughout the city, including standing guard, complete with rifles and bayonets, outside the state Capitol. The National Guard was deployed throughout Nashville for several days after King's assassination. Guardsmen were also deployed in Memphis. Reach Joel Ebert at jebert@tennessean.com or 615-772-1681 and on Twitter @joelebert29. Read or Share this story: https://www.tennessean.com/story/news/politics/2020/05/31/national-guard-deployed-saturday-nashville-protest/5299573002/

title: 75 National Guardsmen were deployed Saturday in Nashville during protests
text: Faced with the possibility of additional violence, Gov. Bill Lee said Sunday he is increasing a deployment of the Tennessee National Guard to help with law enforcement, this time in all three divisions of the state. The governor made the announcement one day after 75 guardsmen were deployed in Nashville in response to an eruption of violence. The rancor occurred after a peaceful rally attended by thousands of Tennesseans who were protesting police brutality and racism. The governor did not say how many and exactly where the guardsmen will be deployed Sunday. Additionally, Lee announced a joint effort between the Tennessee Bureau of Investigation and local law enforcement to investigate Saturday's violence in Nashville, which he said was provoked by many non-Tennesseans. “The right to peaceful protest is foundational to our country, but the violence and vandalism that occurred in Nashville last night was unlawful and tears at the fabric of our community,” Lee said in a statement. “We have reason to believe that many of those involved in unlawful acts are not Tennesseans and we will be working with law enforcement to investigate this further and bring those responsible to justice.” The violence occurred hours after thousands of people gathered near the Capitol for a peaceful rally, following the death of George Floyd in Minneapolis. Organizers of Saturday's rally urged participants to remain peaceful but violence later erupted throughout the city's downtown area, including windows being smashed and a fire being set at the city's historic Metro Courthouse, which includes city hall offices. In total, 28 Metro Nashville police arrested 28 people Saturday night, many after the 10 p.m. curfew. Of those, 21 are from Nashville, four from elsewhere in Tennessee and three from out of state: Texas, Illinois and New York. Saturday's deployment of the National Guard, which was aimed at providing assistance to the Tennessee Highway Patrol and Metro Police Department, was likely the first such move for law enforcement purposes in decades. The guardsmen first reported to the Capitol grounds, where a statue was toppled over. The troops later moved to Lower Broadway, to provide assistance after businesses were damaged. Metro Nashville Police and protesters scuffle outside Central Precint in Nashville, Tenn., Saturday, May 30, 2020 after the “I Will Breathe” rally to protest the death of George Floyd, an unarmed black man who died after being pinned down by a white Minneapolis police officer on Memorial Day. (Photo: Andrew Nelles / The Tennessean) David Roberson, a spokesman for the Department of General Services, said the extent of damage to state-owned property included graffiti and broken windows and doors. Roberson said windows were broken at the War Memorial building, the Rachel Jackson and Andrew Jackson buildings and Citizens Plaza, where graffiti was also found. A door was broken at the state Supreme Court. Graffiti was found on the Capitol grounds, including on a wall. The toppled statue was to be removed Sunday. Roberson said there are no estimates of the total cost of the various damage to state-owned properties. Lee's deployment of the National Guard came at the request of Nashville Mayor John Cooper, said Laine Arnold, the governor's spokeswoman. The governor made the announcement shortly after 9 p.m. Lee signed an executive order, effectively affirming a 10 p.m. curfew Cooper implemented. "I mobilized the National Guard to assist in protecting the lives and property of Tennesseans, which is a critical responsibility of government," the governor's executive order stated. The governor signed another executive order on Sunday to once again coincide with Nashville's latest curfew, which is set for 8 p.m. Tennessee's last major deployment of its National Guard for law enforcement purposes occurred in 1968, after the assassination of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. As many as 4,000 guardsmen were deployed in Nashville the day King was murdered, according to The Tennessean's archives. Troops were stationed throughout the city, including standing guard, complete with rifles and bayonets, outside the state Capitol. The National Guard was deployed throughout Nashville for several days after King's assassination. Guardsmen were also deployed in Memphis. Reach Joel Ebert at jebert@tennessean.com or 615-772-1681 and on Twitter @joelebert29. title: Nashville's Mayor Cooper puts in place 8 p.m. curfew Sunday; says 'healing' turned to 'hooliganism'
text: "And the people shouted with a great shout; so that the wall fell down." The words of a Bible verse, carved on a plaque hung outside the Nashville courthouse to commemorate the civil rights movement in Nashville, were smashed to pieces Saturday and replaced with spray painted profanities. The windows of city hall were smashed using the granite pieces, giving people access to start multiple fires inside and outside the very same civic plaza where 60 years ago thousands marched to end segregation. Mayor John Cooper closely watched events unfold Saturday night, following the "I Will Breathe" rally he attended earlier in the day organized to decry police brutality and the killing of George Floyd in Minneapolis and other black men and women in Nashville and across the country. When a standoff between police, protesters and others turned tense, Cooper said he knew further action was needed. Coordinating with Gov. Bill Lee, Cooper a few hours later declared a state of emergency in the city, imposed a curfew and requested Lee bring in the Tennessee National Guard. But when hundreds of phones buzzed on the Public Square Park lawn, notifying those outside they will be arrested if they violate the 10 p.m. curfew, the emergency alerts went largely ignored as some lobbed water bottles and rocks at police, who, wearing riot gear, returned tear gas and flash bangs. By the end of the night, at least 30 Nashville businesses were damaged as crowds moved to Lower Broadway. The Metro Nashville Police Department arrested 28 people. City leaders and the public watching the mayhem play out in images and videos condemned certain actions. "A healing event evolved into simple hooliganism," Cooper said as he sat in the mayor's office Sunday morning after walking through the damage at what is now being investigated as an arson site. "(Metro Courthouse) has been the scene of social justice improvement," he said. "Ironic is too small of a word to use here." An 8 p.m. curfew was in place Sunday and will be considered on a day-to day-basis going forward, he said, along with his executive order as other cities have seen repeated days of protests. The National Guard will continue to assist as needed. Rally organizers: Concerns shouldn't be overshadowed While organizers of the rally have said the events that happened after the rally were not a part of their efforts, they say the frustrations expressed Saturday should not be overshadowed by the actions of a few. "I'm irritated about how the narrative is changing to how people are protesting to what the real problem is," said Odessa Kelly, executive director of Stand Up Nashville. "Rioting is the language of people who feel their voices are never heard. I'm tired of hearing peaceful protests. Do we want that to happen? Yes. But the crux of that is that we have a messed up system here. The police system needs to be fixed to not allow these atrocities to happen," Kelly said. Attention from city leaders, she said, has moved to condemnation rather than how they can use their position and platforms to address the issues the black community has talked about for decades. Nashville Mayor John Cooper moves through the crowd gathered Saturday, May 30, 2020, for the “I Will Breathe” rally to protest the death of George Floyd, an unarmed black man who died after being pinned down by a white Minneapolis police officer on Memorial Day. (Photo: Larry McCormack/ The Tennessean) The Equity Alliance had to release a statement Saturday night when protesting turned violent that they were not associated with the events outside the courthouse. “It was frustrating to come out and say we didn’t do it because we don’t want people to feel like they can’t express themselves; that their anger or frustration is unheard or we are particularly condemning their frustration or anger,” said Tequila Johnson, co-executive director of The Equity Alliance. “At the same time, we have to be diligent and say there were bad apples with the intention of destroying property. We don’t stand by that, we don’t encourage that,” she said. Protests ripple across nation Protests have rippled across the country after the deaths this month of Floyd, a 46-year-old black man, and Breonna Taylor, a 26-year-old black woman, in Louisville. Floyd died after a white Minneapolis police officer kept a knee pressed into his neck for more than eight minutes. Taylor, an aspiring nurse, was killed in her apartment, shot at least eight times by Louisville police officers who officials have said were executing a warrant. The ongoing debate over policing and racial bias has been prominent in Nashville for years. In 2018, white police officer Andrew Delke shot Daniel Hambrick, 25, a black man, while he was running away during a foot pursuit. Before that, white police officer Josh Lippert shot and killed Jocques Clemmons after a traffic stop, foot chase and confrontation in the James A. Cayce Homes. Protesters gather in Nashville, Tenn., Saturday, May 30, 2020 for the “I Will Breathe” rally to protest the death of George Floyd, an unarmed black man who died after being pinned down by a white Minneapolis police officer on Memorial Day. (Photo: Larry McCormack/ The Tennessean) Debate has raged on about who was out in downtown Nashville on Saturday night and with what agenda, just as in other cities across the country. Police said they are trying to identify individuals who hijacked a peaceful protest against racism and used it “as a cover for the destruction they wanted to employ.” Many seen leading vandalism outside the police central precinct and city hall were white, with several instances of black protesters trying to stop them from inciting violence. Still, many local residents were out protesting and expressing their frustrations, though they were perhaps not a part of Nashville's established social justice groups. But it has prompted questions from those who asked why one would wreck their own community. The answer is complicated, especially for marginalized groups that say they have been squeezed out during Nashville's recent boom years. "To me, the courthouse being burnt out is less about the actual thing but a personification of what has happened to black people on a larger scale," Johnson said. "When you saw that courthouse burning, it was a reflection of what a lot of people here are feeling right now. They feel the burn inside from mistreatment, marginalization, from oppression." Graffiti is on a wall on 2nd Ave. in Nashville, Tenn., Saturday, May 30, 2020 after the “I Will Breathe” rally to protest the death of George Floyd, an unarmed black man who died after being pinned down by a white Minneapolis police officer on Memorial Day. (Photo: Andrew Nelles / The Tennessean) Kelly, who leads the coalition of community organizers and labor unions created to ensure community involvement in city growth and development, called it a "ticking time bomb." "Any time we rebuild or vitalize the city, it's done off the backs of black people who are being pushed out of the city." Beyond policing, there are compounding issues including lack of affordable housing, cost burden and further stigma. "All that goes into what happened last night," Kelly said. "People burning down property is not good but that can be restored. People's lives cannot be restored. So when we equate to two in the same breath, that's where I'm irritated and looking for our leadership to step up." Cooper: 'We want to adjust' “Of course we want to adjust," Cooper said Sunday, when asked how his administration plans to address the calls for changes. "You have to acknowledge the failures of keeping the full American promise to everybody for equal justice under law. It's a constant challenge and something we have struggled with." The reality as a result of the past few months with COVID-19 and the March tornado, he said, has meant his office hasn't been a platform for much change, instead, one of "healing and delivering services." Metro Council's Minority Caucus penned a letter to Cooper on Saturday, telling him that listening to the concerns of the black community will not suffice and that action is necessary. The city, wrote at-large council member and caucus chair Sharon Hurt, must call for support of the oversight board and accountability of police. Cooper must also fund body cameras, send a fair share of CARES Act relief for COVID-19 directly to the black community and also ensure more economic equity in Metro contracts with black businesses. The city, Hurt said, also needs a chief diversity officer in the administration. "We want to address that," Cooper said, about the calls to action heard Saturday during the rally. Chants broke out Saturday to defund police and for Anderson to resign. People gather in Nashville, Tenn., Saturday, May 30, 2020 for the "I Will Breathe" rally to protest the death of George Floyd, an unarmed black man who died after being pinned down by a white Minneapolis police officer on Memorial Day. (Photo: Larry McCormack/ The Tennessean) Cooper pointed out the "quality policing" seen Saturday night and said the city should also get credit for other areas it has been effective in, including the agreement between Metro police and the Community Oversight Board. The city, he said, will have a full body camera program when it's past its "crisis budget." But advocates and members of the Community Oversight Board have been critical of police Chief Steve Anderson and the police department for failing to cooperate with the civilian panel and the very idea that an agreement is necessary to get one Metro department to work with another. Asked if he supported Anderson, Cooper said what played out Saturday on live television showed the actions of the police department working well in a very difficult moment. "He is the chief. And I think deservingly should take some credit," Cooper said. Cooper ended a interview before he could respond to a question asked about Metro police's relationship with the oversight board. Jamel Campbell-Gooch, deputy director of Gideon's Army and the vice chair of the oversight board, said the time has come for not asking but demanding changes. Residents can push to make sure the oversight board has access to information from the police department, call for the city to get rid of bad officers and push for changes to the budget to make changes to public safety on the front end, Campbell-Gooch said. “There are things we can be reaching for locally right now,” he said. “It’s time. All the changes they want to see need to be invested by the mayor’s office to actually stop violence.” Read or Share this story: https://www.tennessean.com/story/news/politics/2020/05/31/nashville-mayor-john-cooper-curfew-sunday-night/5299774002/

title: Nashville's George Floyd rally was peaceful. Scoundrels spawned the violence. | Editorial
text: CLOSE Demonstrators gather for 'I Will Breathe' rally to protest death of George Floyd Nashville Tennessean People of different races and backgrounds gathered to denounce racism and injustice. The violence ensued afterward and it was an attempt to set back civil rights progress in Nashville. Story Highlights David Plazas is the director of opinion and engagement for the USA TODAY Network Tennessee. Nashville wanted and deserved a peaceful protest on Saturday. The afternoon rally at Tennessee’s Legislative Plaza in downtown Nashville was peaceful and an amazing example of civic engagement and good citizenship. The violence that ensued after it finished, perpetrated by troublemakers separate from rally organizers, was atrocious and an affront to basic decency. The Old Courthouse that houses city hall was set on fire. A plaque commemorating the protests of 1960 that ended the desegregation of lunch counters was destroyed. Downtown businesses were vandalized and looted. The bad actors, whoever they are, wanted to stain Nashville, delegitimize the rally, sow distrust among citizens and set our civil rights progress way behind. It is important to decouple the two events. CLOSE Protesters set fire outside a window at Nashville's Metropolitan Courthouse Saturday, May 30, 2020 Nashville Tennessean Nashville's civil rights history is complicated In the first, more than a thousand people of diverse races and backgrounds gathered to denounce police brutality, demand justice for African Americans and communities of color, and call for transformational systemic change that has disproportionately kept marginalized people from benefiting from America’s promise. The afternoon rally was inspired by the brutal and unjustified killing of George Floyd, an African American man, by a police officer in Minneapolis on May 25. Derek Chauvin was fired from the police force and is now charged with Floyd’s murder. People gather on Legislative Plaza in Nashville, Tenn., Saturday, May 30, 2020 for the “I Will Breathe” rally to protest the death of George Floyd, an unarmed black man who died after being pinned down by a white Minneapolis police officer on Memorial Day. (Photo: Larry McCormack/ The Tennessean) Nashville has a complicated legacy when it comes to civil rights. The student sit-in movement was birthed, nurtured and sustained in Music City. But the remnants of segregation persist in housing patterns and displacement and in inequitable access to health care, education and job opportunities. African Americans and communities of color are disproportionately incarcerated at a higher rate than white citizens. The COVID-19 pandemic has further exposed the problem; African Americans are getting sicker and dying at a disproportionately higher rate than their white peers. In addition, Metro Nashville Police Department’s handling of the killings of two black men — Jocques Clemmons in 2017 and Daniel Hambrick in 2018 — at the hands of white police officers has been highly criticized. So much so, that 60% of Nashville voters approved a community oversight board of police in November 2018. The African American community’s call for such a board had been made for at least 40 years. To his credit, Metro Nashville Police Department Chief Steve Anderson — who has long been a target of community criticism for over policing minority communities — condemned Floyd’s killing. Blame the perpetrators of violence for the mayhem Metro Nashville-Davidson County Mayor John Cooper invited the Metro Council and the community to join him at Saturday’s peaceful rally. It was a call for unity, peace and collaboration at a fraught time in our nation and contrasted the divisive, toxic and violent rhetoric of other leaders. On his social media posts, Cooper has faced criticism from people blaming him for the violence. But he is not to blame. The people who committed the atrocious acts are, and they should be held accountable for their misdeeds. Nashville is in a state of stress and healing in the aftermath of the March 3 tornadoes, COVID-19, the economic fallout from the pandemic and now Saturday night’s violence. However, it is incumbent upon our leaders and fellow citizens to continue to do the work, despite the setbacks, struggles and frustration, to move Nashville toward a place where equity and inclusion are not just talked about but are achieved by all in the community. We cannot be deterred. We will not be deterred. Opinion and Engagement Director David Plazas wrote this editorial on behalf of The Tennessean Editorial Board, which comprises Regional Editor Michael A. Anastasi Editor, Executive Editor Maria De Varenne and Plazas. Call him at (615) 259-8063, email him at dplazas@tennessean.com or tweet to him at @davidplazas. Subscribe and support local journalism. Read or Share this story: https://www.tennessean.com/story/opinion/columnists/david-plazas/2020/05/31/nashville-george-floyd-peaceful-rally-later-violence/5299877002/

title: Photos: Protests In Response To The Death Of George Floyd Shake The Nation
text: Demonstrators and police clashed this weekend as anguish and rage swept through cities across the U.S. in response to the death of George Floyd. Protesters were tear-gassed, police cars destroyed, buildings vandalized and businesses looted in some of the nation's worst civil unrest in years. Here's a look at some of the cities.

title: Woman charged with rioting in downtown Memphis
text: MEMPHIS, Tenn. — Multiple people are facing charges after a second demonstration in downtown Memphis on Saturday night. According to a Facebook post from the Memphis Police Department, this began around 11:33 p.m. while police were trying to disperse a crowd in the area of Beale Street and Main Street. Officers gave an order for the crowd to disperse and several people got mad and allegedly jumped on top of squad cars. Additional officers were called in and bike racks were used to help contain the crowd. MPD says the crowds began to push through the bike racks and officers, causing the racks to fall over. The two individuals and officers holding down the bike racks fell to the ground. Officers also say they saw several people throwing bottles into the crowd from a rooftop in the area of B.B. King and Beale Street. According to police, people were throwing fireworks at them and rocks were thrown at businesses and squad cars for several hours. People were driving erratically and MPD received multiple shots-fired calls. Around 2:30 a.m., a person driving near Beale Street and Fourth allegedly fired shots at an officer. The officer was not hit but the suspect was taken into custody. Another person shot at an officer an hour later but the alleged suspect fled the scene and has not been taken into custody. Memphis Police Department Director Michael Rallings released a statement on Facebook surrounding the fact police were wearing riot gear: “Some have asked why our officers were wearing riot gear protection. I feel that this question is asked because some do not know all of the details. Clearly, you can see that our officers were wearing riot gear protection to protect themselves and so that they can protect our citizens. I have said that we support peaceful protest, but we will not stand by and let the few that want to wreak havoc tear down our city. The peaceful protest that took place earlier in the day was powerful and had meaning. The riot that occurred later in the downtown area only brought chaos and civil unrest. My hat goes off to those who seek justice through peaceful protest; they have meaning, heart, and purpose.” Michael Rallings, Dir. of Memphis Police Department Local Activist Hunter Demster witnessed the events from Saturday night and says there is far more to the story. “I don’t understand how they can’t grasp that to form that line of riot cops brandishing their billy clubs, paramilitary assault uniforms, AR-15s, how that is not going to escalate the situation,” Demster said. Multiple people were taken into custody and are facing weapon charges, obstruction of roadways, rioting and evading arrest. Activists say that many of the people arrested Saturday were not a part of the protest and took issue with the arrests. Victoria Jones, Geno McGary, Damion Smith, Kameron Miller, Likisha Davis and Rodney White have since been released on their own recognizance.

title: Target Says It Will Temporarily Close Stores In Several States As Protests Continue
text: Amid continuing protests over the death of George Floyd, Target has temporarily closed or adjusted hours at more than 200 stores nationwide. The announcement on Saturday from the nation's eighth largest retailer came after Target stores in multiple cities became scenes of violence and unrest. Among the stores where aisles were ransacked was a Target in Minneapolis located near the city's 3rd police precinct, where the four officers who were fired after Floyd's death worked. The station was damaged by a fire last week. "We are heartbroken by the death of George Floyd and the pain it is causing communities across the country," the Minneapolis-based company said in a statement. "At this time, we have made the decision to close a number of our stores." A Target spokesperson said that the company is evaluating closures and limiting hours on a store-by-store basis. The majority of stores being closed are located in Minnesota, and in California, where protests in Los Angeles led the National Guard to be deployed. Stores will also close in Colorado, Illinois, Oregon and Pennsylvania. Despite the violence that has hit its stores, the company has voiced support for demonstrators. "The murder of George Floyd has unleashed the pent-up pain of years, as have the killings of Ahmaud Arbery and Breonna Taylor," Target CEO Brian Cornell wrote in a public letter on Friday. "We say their names and hold a too-long list of others in our hearts." It remains unclear whether the looting at Target stores was committed by demonstrators or whether they were the actions of unaffiliated bad actors. But the ongoing demonstrations have focused scrutiny on Target's past work with law enforcement — including partnerships with agencies in at least 2o cities. In Minneapolis, the company partnered with police on a program that helped install closed-circuit television cameras in the downtown area. A 2010 report released with support from the company said the "genesis of the program was a widespread feeling some years ago in the city of Minneapolis that the downtown business district was not a pleasant place to work or visit."

title: Trump Lays Blame For Clashes On 'Radical-Left Anarchists'
text: Updated at 3:30 p.m. ET As overlapping crises convulsed an anxious nation, President Trump on Sunday sought to cast blame for widespread protests gripping cities on "radical-left anarchists," while also adding that the media "is doing everything within their power to foment hatred and anarchy." The president has said that members of the loosely defined far-left group Antifa — short for "anti-fascists" — have led clashes with police and looting in cities across the country since the killing of a black man in police custody in Minneapolis. It's unclear if any group or groups are primarily responsible for escalating protests that began following George Floyd's death on May 25 as Minneapolis police officer Derek Chauvin held his knee on Floyd's neck. Minnesota Gov. Tim Walz, a Democrat, has told the press he'd heard unconfirmed reports that white supremacists were coming from elsewhere to stoke the violence. In one tweet Sunday, Trump said the United States "will be designating ANTIFA as a Terrorist Organization." It's something he's previously floated, and last year two Republican senators introduced a resolution that sought to designate the group as a domestic terrorist organization. Following Trump's tweet, Attorney General William Barr said in a statement that "[f]ederal law enforcement actions will be directed at apprehending and charging the violent radical agitators who have hijacked peaceful protest." Barr added: "The violence instigated and carried out by Antifa and other similar groups in connection with the rioting is domestic terrorism and will be treated accordingly." The clashes, spreading to dozens of cities across the U.S., follow a series of racist incidents and deaths of black people, including Floyd's on Monday. Chauvin, now a former Minneapolis police officer, was seen on video kneeling on Floyd's neck while holding him in custody, as Floyd pleaded that he couldn't breathe. Chauvin has been charged with third-degree murder and manslaughter. Three other officers present at the scene have been fired, but not arrested or charged. Protests and clashes that have since followed come at a time of unprecedented crisis for the country, with confirmed deaths from the coronavirus pandemic topping 100,000 and millions out of work as a result of broad business shutdowns. Minorities, including African Americans, have been disproportionately affected by COVID-19 deaths and pandemic-induced economic peril. "The death of George Floyd on the streets of Minneapolis was a grave tragedy. It should never have happened. It has filled Americans all over the country with horror, anger, and grief." pic.twitter.com/lirAMSv4Wo — The White House (@WhiteHouse) May 30, 2020 Trump addressed the demonstrations Saturday, striking a milder tone during prepared remarks following a manned space launch in Florida than he has on Twitter. He said Floyd's death "has filled Americans all over the country with horror, anger and grief." He added that he "understands the pain that people are feeling" and supports peaceful protest, but that "the memory of George Floyd is being dishonored by rioters, looters and anarchists." "He should just sometimes stop talking" Apart from Saturday's remarks, though, Trump has not often played a unifying role in recent days. His tweets about radical-left anarchists have also included criticism of Democratic leadership in Minnesota. In another tweet on Sunday he blamed the mainstream media for fomenting "hatred and anarchy." Time for a change! #2020 https://t.co/AECy2GBfys — Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump) May 30, 2020 On Friday, Trump tweeted provocatively that "when the looting starts, the shooting starts," a phrase with a racist history that Trump said he was not aware of. Later on, he said his intent was not to make a threat, but to register a statement of concern that armed violence can accompany looting. Sen. Tim Scott, a South Carolina Republican, said on Fox News Sunday that the president's tweets about demonstrations turning violent are "not constructive." Speaking on ABC's This Week, House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, D-Calif., said on Sunday morning that she's not paying attention to Trump's inflammatory tweets. Instead, she said he "should be a unifying force in our country. We have seen that with Democratic and Republican presidents all along. They have seen their responsibility to be the president of the United States, to unify our country, and not to fuel the flame." Also Sunday, Keisha Lance Bottoms — mayor of Atlanta, one city that's seen protests and clashes with police — told CBS' Face The Nation that Trump's tweets are "making it worse" and "he should just sometimes stop talking." In his own statement Saturday, former Vice President Joe Biden, the presumptive Democratic nominee for president, wrote that "protesting [Floyd's killing] is right and necessary. It's an utterly American response. But burning down communities and needless destruction is not. Violence that endangers lives is not." He added that as president, he'd lead the conversation about turning the nation's "anguish to purpose."

title: President Trump wants to declare antifa a terrorist group. Here's what we know about their Tennessee activities.
text: President Donald Trump has announced he intends to designate a militant anti-racist movement a terrorist organization as violent protests attended by a variety of activists have erupted in cities around the country, including Nashville. The protests, some of which have resulted in destruction of property and violent clashes with police, are being held in response to police killing George Floyd in Minneapolis and other black individuals who have recently died at the hands of law enforcement. "The United States of America will be designating ANTIFA as a Terrorist Organization," Trump said during remarks at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida on Saturday, though it's unclear by what legal mechanism he can designate a domestic organization to be a terrorist group. Antifa, short for anti-fascist, is a left-wing activist movement active globally, including in Tennessee. The loosely affiliated groups frequently advocate for anti-racist policies, though often take an anarchist and militant approach. There is no formal leadership or unified national structure to the movement. It is not one organization, but rather loose network of activists using a "black bloc" tactic at protests — dressing in all black and concealing their faces with masks and bandannas. Multiple antifa groups have been based in Nashville in recent years. No clear evidence antifa organized violent protests in Nashville While many of the protesters in Nashville on Saturday fit that description, it's unclear if any affiliate with antifa organizations. Metro Nashville Police Department Chief Steve Anderson said Sunday the city is investigating a small group of people they believe used the protest as a cover for violence and other criminal acts. The police chief did not say if any organized groups might be behind the violence in Nashville. A peaceful rally held downtown Saturday afternoon evolved throughout the evening, eventually turning from a march into a chaotic eruption of vandalism to public and private property. Metro Nashville's historic courthouse and city hall were set afire in the process, among other significant damage the building sustained. Antifa groups have, however, openly mobilized overwhelmingly nonviolent counterprotests at events like the October 2017 "White Lives Matter Rally" in Shelbyville and Murfreesboro, as well as made appearances at the annual American Renaissance conference held at Tennessee's Montgomery Bell State Park. The conference, which was canceled this year due to the coronavirus and therefore did not prompt a protest, is held by a white nationalist organization. The protest groups are typically met with a large number of park rangers and forced to demonstrate behind barriers, limiting the possibility for physical confrontations with the conference-goers. While some small altercations have taken place between protesters and counterprotesters at those events, there is no evidence that antifa activists have been responsible for inciting any type of significant violence in Tennessee. They frequently inhabit a very insular online space, trading jabs with individuals they believe to espouse white supremacist beliefs. As with other antifa activists around the nation, Jam City Antifa, a Nashville-based network, has been known to track area white supremacists and post photos and other identifying information about them online, sometimes encouraging followers to show up to heckle them at events. White supremacists have in turn done the same for antifa activists in the area. Last year, U.S. Rep. Tim Burchett, R-Knoxville, filed the "Unmasking Antifa Act," legislation that sought to punish up to 15 years a person wearing a mask or disguise while committing a crime, including threatening or intimidating another individual "exercising their constitutional rights or privileges," according to a statement from Burchett's office at the time. "It’s time we get tough on this issue. These cowards wouldn’t act the way they do if the whole world could see their faces,” Burchett said at the time, which was pre-coronavirus pandemic. Trump's administration quick to cast blame on antifa amid protests U.S. Attorney General William Barr on Sunday also blamed antifa and other similar groups over the violent protests around the country. Barr did not say what specific groups may have been involved or where they came from, but he said the Justice Department and the FBI will work on identifying “criminal organizers and instigators” to be arrested and charged Trump's national security advisor Robert O'Brien told CNN Sunday that the administration planned to "get to the bottom" of antifa's role in the protests. And he said the president and Barr want to know what the FBI is doing to "to track and dismantle and surveil and prosecute antifa." O'Brien denounced "these antifa militant radicals who come into our cities and cross state lines. "They're organized, and use Molotov cocktails and fireworks and gas to burn down our cities, especially businesses in minority neighborhoods. It's got to be stopped," he said on "State of the Union." But some have blamed right-wing provocateurs seeking to incite a race war for the violence. "The truth is nobody really knows," Minnesota Attorney General Keith Ellison said Sunday on NBC News' "Meet the Press." "What the exact political motivation is is unclear at this point. We need to investigate it," Ellison said. USA Today and Adam Tamburin contributed to this report. Reach Natalie Allison at nallison@tennessean.com. Follow her on Twitter at @natalie_allison. Want to read more stories like this? A subscription to one of our Tennessee publications gets you unlimited access to all the latest politics news, podcasts like Grand Divisions, plus newsletters, a personalized mobile experience and the ability to tap into stories, photos and videos from throughout the USA TODAY Network's 261 daily sites. title: Nashville honky tonks assess damage, express hope for a brighter future
text: CLOSE Members of The Stage's staff fortified themselves in the business' back office Saturday night as people broke through the Broadway bar's windows. They had closed early as a peaceful protest against police brutality and the killing of George Floyd was followed by destruction in downtown Nashville. The staff, unable to leave in time, waited for it to end. When the sun rose Sunday, it revealed broken glass, a smashed cash register, stage equipment dragged into the street and potential evidence that someone tried — unsuccessfully — to start a fire. At least 30 businesses were damaged overnight. "We've had a lot of folks helping (clean up), and that's the main thing, that everybody's OK," owner Brenda Sanderson told The Tennessean on Sunday morning. Multiple community members volunteered in the cleanup effort Sunday, scrubbing spray paint off walls, boarding windows and sweeping shattered glass. Tom Morales, owner of Acme Feed & Seed and The Southern, said Nashville faces the challenge of rebuilding both its businesses and public trust. His businesses made it through unmarred. "I really believe the people who are trying to deliver the message (against police brutality) were hijacked by a small group of men, boys and kids that society produces because they're trapped in a situation where they have no opportunity," Morales said. The Equity Alliance, which organized the peaceful demonstration attended by both protesters and local officials Saturday afternoon, condemned the violence Sunday, stating that "those individuals defacing and destroying public property after the rally were not a part of the original event." In Morales' view, discrimination, the existing financial struggles of many and the widespread impacts of the pandemic brought tensions to a boiling point. "You look at all of the broken parts of American society, and this is revealing it (all), and that's the sad part," Morales said. "This is endemic of how frustrated people get," he said. "When Americans go one week (without pay) and they're out of money, and now they're going to start evicting them, the height of the frustration has not even gotten to the ivory towers yet. If we don't, as a country, come together, all of these towers they're building in Nashville are going to be like gravestones." Steve Smith, owner of Tootsie's, Honky Tonk Central and Rippy's Bar and Grill, said none of his buildings were damaged and no one in his establishments was hurt. "It's horrible," he said. "People should be out lighting candles for this young man that got killed. They shouldn't be out burning businesses down and destroying property." Smith's bars have long staffed armed security guards, and Smith said they've been told to shoot if anyone puts their customers or staff in danger. "If somebody comes in and sets your house on fire, are you going to shoot them?" Smith said. "I am." Nashville police officers stand near the shattered windows at Jimmy Buffett's Margaritaville on Saturday, May 30, 2020, one of several Lower Broadway businesses that were damaged following protests against police violence and the killing of George Floyd. (Photo: Andrew Nelles / The Tennessean) Butch Spyridon, president of the Nashville Convention and Visitors Corp., said he was hopeful that Sunday would be a better day for everyone in Nashville. "I'm without question at a loss for words, stunned by what I saw, and sad for Nashville, because that's not who we are," he said. Spyridon does not yet know the extent of the damage, but he estimated it could be hundreds of thousands of dollars based on what he saw unfold on television. Although repairs will slow the city's recovery from the economic impact of the coronavirus pandemic, Spyridon has faith in Nashville's ability to bounce back. After the streets cleared Saturday night, a construction worker began boarding up broken windows along Broadway on his own volition. He's an example of Nashville's strength, Spyridon said. "That's Nashville, responding immediately, even faster than immediately — that's the sign of who we are," he said. Jessica Bliss contributed to this report. Reach Cassandra Stephenson at ckstephenson@tennessean.com or at (731) 694-7261. Follow Cassandra on Twitter at @CStephenson731. Read or Share this story: https://www.tennessean.com/story/news/2020/05/31/nashville-honky-tonks-assess-damage-express-hope-brighter-future/5299713002/

title: Ryman Auditorium Window Smashed In Violent Nashville Riots - Country Now
text: Peaceful protests turned violent in Nashville on Saturday (May 30) when looters took to the streets of Music City and destroyed storefronts and set fire various buildings, including the Nashville courthouse. As the protestors moved to Broadway, Twitter exploded with comments about Nashville’s famed Ryman Auditorium and questions about whether or not the iconic venue sustained damage. Yihyun Jeong, a reporter for The Tennessean, cleared the air, revealing that the Ryman sustained minimal damage. According to Jeong’s post on Twitter, only one of the venue’s windows was smashed. Security on-site confirmed that was the only damage to the Ryman. One window got smashed at the Ryman Auditorium. Security outside said no other damage. pic.twitter.com/16EnAaQYXn — Yihyun Jeong (@yihyun_jeong) May 31, 2020 The violent acts forced Metro Nashville Mayor John Cooper to issue an emergency order and Metro Nashville Police issued a curfew for 10 pm local time. Tennessee Governor Bill Lee also authorized the National Guard to be deployed. Earlier in the day, a peaceful protest took place in Nashville where thousands took to the streets to demand justice for the murder of George Floyd and to demand an end police brutality. UPDATE: A News Channel 5 report confirmed another window was damaged.
