title: In Tennessee, peaceful demonstrations by day turned destructive after dark
text: Thousands in Tennessee massed to protest against police brutality. What carried forth as peaceful demonstrations by day turned destructive in some communities after dark. City sites scorched by arson, historic buildings marred by graffiti and a state of emergency declared by city leaders in response to the unrest. It has left communities across Tennessee shaken, and as tensions mount, it's unclear what's to come. What is certain is residents statewide joined together to scrub graffiti, board up broken windows and sweep shards of glass from the streets as activists and city leaders look for solutions. "There's a historic anger, and there's an historic lack of trust in the community, and right now we need calm, compassionate leadership. We don't need confrontation," said Nashville business owner Tom Morales, who operates Acme Feed & Seed on Broadway where unrest erupted Saturday night. "We cannot ignore what creates the problem. ... I think that a bunch of (instigators) hijacked a positive message." Protests have rippled across the country decrying the brutal force used against George Floyd, a 46-year-old black man who died after a white Minneapolis police officer kept a knee pressed on his neck for more than eight minutes. Demonstrations came to Tennessee on Saturday as peaceful gatherings of hundreds and thousands took place in Nashville, Knoxville, Chattanooga and Jackson. Memphis staged its fourth day of protests. A peaceful protest in front of Jackson City Hall occurred Saturday, May 30, 2020 in the afternoon. The protestors helds signs reading "Black Lives Matter" and “I can’t breathe” after George Floyd's death May 25 in Minneapolis. (Photo: Stephanie Amador / The Jackson Sun) But as dusk fell, what had been nonviolent became tense. "The threat to both peace and property is unacceptable and we will work with local law enforcement and community leaders to restore safety and order," Tennessee Gov. Bill Lee wrote on Twitter. "This is not a reflection of our state or the fundamental American right to peaceful protest." Unrest in Memphis, Chattanooga and Knoxville In Memphis, about two hours after a demonstration against police brutality ended peacefully Saturday, a chaotic few seconds changed the tone. In a dramatic standoff, some people who remained in the crowd of about 60 demonstrators crossed a barricade near the Orpheum Theatre, which was set up to separate protesters from police. When they did, horses holding mounted officers spooked and shuffled. Barricades tumbled to the ground and people fell down. Police moved forward. Glass bottles flew through the air. The unrest marked a shift from the previous days — and that night's earlier events during which demonstrators marched and police largely let demonstrations play out on their own, without interference or arrests. Most of the crowd from Saturday's protest left around 9 p.m. from the National Civil Rights Museum, a short walk from Beale Street. But several dozen stayed. By 11:30 p.m., there were about 35 officers with riot shields, including one armed with a long gun, on the scene near the crowd. stand (Photo: Joe Rondone) A key leader of the earlier protest, DeVante Hill, commented on Twitter: "Tonight just when I thought things were over and we could successfully say we had a peaceful protest, there were young men and women who staggered around near Beale and Main. MPD definitely (incited) them with riot gear, horses and AR-15s ..." "I really believe we can do this. I truly believe we can do this another way. A crowd of 30 staggering people met with intense force like that is just uneasy for not only me to understand but a group of my other white brothers and sisters present as well," Hill wrote. In Chattanooga on Saturday night, overturned trash cans littered the streets as protesters threw rocks and at least one firework, sending others scattering as it exploded. Groups of demonstrators crowded Market Street after midnight, and several arrests were made. A crowd moved quickly through Market Square in Knoxville late Saturday night, smashing windows and destroying planters. Two men were arrested in separate incidents, including a 20-year-old male with six handguns, two shotguns, two rifles and narcotics. In the unrest, activist and former Knoxville City Council candidate David Hayes said on social media that he was shot with pepper-filled balls by police while he was escorting young protesters. Nashville activist: 'The narrative is changing' Nashville, too, saw conflict and destruction erupt in the aftermath of a peaceful protest. The historic Metro Courthouse burned, flames swelling through the first-floor windows. Clouds of tear gas mushroomed across Public Square Plaza. Spray paint tagged the walls. And the granite plaque commemorating Diane Nash, a civil rights leader in Nashville, was broken to pieces — its shards used to shatter windows. It left a mark on a city already scarred by the decimation of deadly tornadoes and the forced isolation of a pandemic. An 8 p.m. curfew was put in place for Nashville on Sunday after Mayor John Cooper, who had earlier Saturday attended the "I Will Breathe" rally to decry police brutality, declared a state of emergency. The order came, even as more demonstrations, including a Sunday vigil honoring Floyd's memory prepared to begin in Murfreesboro. Late morning, several streets leading to the Public Square were blocked by dump trucks and garbage trucks as fencing was set up and business owners preemptively boarded up their windows. "We felt comfortable and knew it would be peaceful," said Scarlett Murphy, who owns Domenico's deli with husband Jeff Murphy. "Then we started getting texts and calls that the people who weren't involved in the peaceful part were also coming, so we decided it would be best to be safe than sorry." At 3:30 p.m., Murfreesboro organizers led a prayer circle where a diverse crowd of approximately 300 people gathered. Attendees chanted, "No justice, no peace," followed by "No racist, no peace," before heading on a march around the square where they continued chanting as they walked. Nashville Mayor John Cooper moves through the crowd gathered Saturday, May 30, 2020, for the “I Will Breathe” rally to protest the death of George Floyd, an unarmed black man who died after being pinned down by a white Minneapolis police officer on Memorial Day. (Photo: Larry McCormack/ The Tennessean) As she reflected on the weekend's events, Odessa Kelly, executive director of activist group Stand Up Nashville, said: "I'm irritated about how the narrative is changing to how people are protesting to what the real problem is." "Rioting is the language of people who feel their voices are never heard. I'm tired of hearing peaceful protests. Do we want that to happen? Yes. But the crux of that is that we have a messed up system here. The police system needs to be fixed to not allow these atrocities to happen." Statewide reporters Yihyun Jeong, Cassandra Stephenson, Kelli Krebs, Chuck Campbell, Allie Clouse, Laura Testino, Desiree Stennett, Daniel Connolly, Corinne S Kennedy, Samuel Hardiman, Nancy DeGennaro, Joseph Spears and Brinley Hineman contributed to this report. Reach Jessica Bliss at 615-259-8253 and jbliss@tennessean.com or on Twitter @jlbliss and please support local journalism. Read or Share this story: https://www.tennessean.com/story/news/2020/05/31/tennessee-peaceful-demonstrations-turn-destructive-after-dark/5299681002/

title: Gov. Lee orders more National Guard members deployed across Tennessee to assist police
text: Faced with the possibility of additional violence, Gov. Bill Lee said Sunday he is increasing a deployment of the Tennessee National Guard to help with law enforcement, this time in all three divisions of the state. The governor made the announcement one day after 75 guardsmen were deployed in Nashville in response to an eruption of violence. The rancor occurred after a peaceful rally attended by thousands of Tennesseans who were protesting police brutality and racism. The governor did not say how many and exactly where the guardsmen will be deployed Sunday. Additionally, Lee announced a joint effort between the Tennessee Bureau of Investigation and local law enforcement to investigate Saturday's violence in Nashville, which he said was provoked by many non-Tennesseans. “The right to peaceful protest is foundational to our country, but the violence and vandalism that occurred in Nashville last night was unlawful and tears at the fabric of our community,” Lee said in a statement. “We have reason to believe that many of those involved in unlawful acts are not Tennesseans and we will be working with law enforcement to investigate this further and bring those responsible to justice.” The violence occurred hours after thousands of people gathered near the Capitol for a peaceful rally, following the death of George Floyd in Minneapolis. Organizers of Saturday's rally urged participants to remain peaceful but violence later erupted throughout the city's downtown area, including windows being smashed and a fire being set at the city's historic Metro Courthouse, which includes city hall offices. In total, 28 Metro Nashville police arrested 28 people Saturday night, many after the 10 p.m. curfew. Of those, 21 are from Nashville, four from elsewhere in Tennessee and three from out of state: Texas, Illinois and New York. Saturday's deployment of the National Guard, which was aimed at providing assistance to the Tennessee Highway Patrol and Metro Police Department, was likely the first such move for law enforcement purposes in decades. The guardsmen first reported to the Capitol grounds, where a statue was toppled over. The troops later moved to Lower Broadway, to provide assistance after businesses were damaged. Metro Nashville Police and protesters scuffle outside Central Precint in Nashville, Tenn., Saturday, May 30, 2020 after the “I Will Breathe” rally to protest the death of George Floyd, an unarmed black man who died after being pinned down by a white Minneapolis police officer on Memorial Day. (Photo: Andrew Nelles / The Tennessean) David Roberson, a spokesman for the Department of General Services, said the extent of damage to state-owned property included graffiti and broken windows and doors. Roberson said windows were broken at the War Memorial building, the Rachel Jackson and Andrew Jackson buildings and Citizens Plaza, where graffiti was also found. A door was broken at the state Supreme Court. Graffiti was found on the Capitol grounds, including on a wall. The toppled statue was to be removed Sunday. Roberson said there are no estimates of the total cost of the various damage to state-owned properties. Lee's deployment of the National Guard came at the request of Nashville Mayor John Cooper, said Laine Arnold, the governor's spokeswoman. The governor made the announcement shortly after 9 p.m. Lee signed an executive order, effectively affirming a 10 p.m. curfew Cooper implemented. "I mobilized the National Guard to assist in protecting the lives and property of Tennesseans, which is a critical responsibility of government," the governor's executive order stated. The governor signed another executive order on Sunday to once again coincide with Nashville's latest curfew, which is set for 8 p.m. Tennessee's last major deployment of its National Guard for law enforcement purposes occurred in 1968, after the assassination of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. As many as 4,000 guardsmen were deployed in Nashville the day King was murdered, according to The Tennessean's archives. Troops were stationed throughout the city, including standing guard, complete with rifles and bayonets, outside the state Capitol. The National Guard was deployed throughout Nashville for several days after King's assassination. Guardsmen were also deployed in Memphis. Reach Joel Ebert at jebert@tennessean.com or 615-772-1681 and on Twitter @joelebert29. Read or Share this story: https://www.tennessean.com/story/news/politics/2020/05/31/national-guard-deployed-saturday-nashville-protest/5299573002/

CRIME IS NOT JUSTICE; NOT ALL COPS ARE BAD! #JUSTICEFORFLOYD #KEEPMURFREESBOROSAFE #KEEPMURFREESBOROCIVIL " during Sunday's protest. Joseph Spears, IndyStar

title: Rally organizers condemn Nashville riot after protests turn violent
text: The "I Will Breathe’ rally to protest police brutality in Nashville on Saturday began to erupt into pockets of violence as marchers moved through downtown. By 8:15 p.m. Saturday, flames could be seen shooting from a first-floor window of the Metro Nashville Courthouse and City Hall. That event led police to issue a 10 p.m. curfew, Mayor John Cooper to declare a state of civil emergency and Gov. Bill Lee to order the National Guard into the city. Multiple people were arrested before the curfew began. “After the arson and vandalism at the courthouse, this has taken on a much different response,” police spokesman Don Aaron said. “Those who continue to harm the city — those who continue to participate in this destruction — are being warned that they’re engaging in unlawful assembly and officers are prepared for arrests.” Police detained people on Broadway after 10 p.m. and urged people on the pedestrian bridge to leave downtown. The afternoon started with a large and peaceful rally at the Legislative Plaza, but problems began to emerge as demonstrators started to march. A little more than a mile from the Capitol, several people were arrested when windows were smashed in a Metro Nashville police cruiser near Sixth Avenue South and Korean Veterans Boulevard; some protesters later threw rocks and bottles at officers. "It's a mess right now," Nashville police central precinct commander Gordon Howey said late Saturday afternoon. About 90 minutes after that first violent confrontation, a handful of protesters had made their way to Nashville's Metro Courthouse and City Hall where some were throwing rocks and smashing windows on the building. Police met those protesters with force but dozens of other demonstrators arrived a short time later; officers under a barrage of rocks and bottles, in the shadow of City Hall, sprayed pepper spray in an attempt to gain control of the situation. Demonstrators smash a Metro Nashville Police car outside Central Precinct in Nashville, Tenn., Saturday, May 30, 2020 after the “I Will Breathe” rally to protest the death of George Floyd, a black man who died after being pinned down by a white Minneapolis police officer on Memorial Day. (Photo: Andrew Nelles / The Tennessean) Organizers of the rally released a statement late Saturday night condemning the violence. “Our organization, in cooperation with other activists, held a peaceful rally today to protest the murder of Minneapolis resident George Floyd by police as well as to deliver a clear message to Metro and state government leaders that Tennesseans deeply oppose racism and police brutality. The event drew some 4,000 attendees and our staff registered over 300 new voters. It was a peaceful assembly," said Charlane Oliver and Tequila Johnson in a statement attributed to the founders and executive directors of The Equity Alliance “It is our firm belief that those individuals defacing and destroying public property after the rally were not a part of the original event. The actions by this small group reflect neither the beliefs of the groups that led today’s peaceful assembly nor those of the majority of the attendees. This behavior dishonors the memory of George Floyd and other black Americans that have died unjustly at the hands of police." PROTEST UPDATES: Protesters marching in downtown Nashville; multiple arrests made The rally began at the Legislative Plaza about 3 p.m. Saturday where several thousand people gathered for a demonstration that included lawmakers and community leaders speaking at the event. Nashville Mayor John Cooper was among them and he encouraged members of the city council to join him. The mayor said it was "an especially critical time for all of us, as Metro’s leaders, to show up and listen to black voices speaking out from across Davidson County." Protesters pack Legislative Plaza in Nashville, Tenn., Saturday, May 30, 2020 for the “I Will Breathe” rally to protest the death of George Floyd, an unarmed black man who died after being pinned down by a white Minneapolis police officer on Memorial Day. (Photo: Larry McCormack/ The Tennessean) After about 90 minutes, the rally had turned into a march, moving through downtown Nashville. It was a little more than a mile to the south of the Legislative Plaza where the first violent clashes occurred. Protesters bashed in the windows of a police cruiser outside the police department's Central Precinct at Sixth Avenue and Korean Veterans Boulevard. By about 6 p.m. Saturday, a series of officers in riot gear with masks, helmets and batons arrived at the precinct. A crowd converged around them and few plastic water bottles flew toward the officers. Officers on horseback soon followed and some in the crowd threw rocks and water bottles toward the officers. The crowd moved down Broadway and through Nashville's popular honky tonk district, with some vandalizing buildings along the way, including Bridgestone Arena. By 7 p.m., a small group of protesters had arrived at City Hall where some were smashing the building's windows with rocks and other items. Tension near City Hall abated for a while, with protesters and officers talking while police held a line. By 8 p.m., a statue outside the state Capital of controversial lawmaker and newspaper publisher Edward Carmack had been torn down. The statue of Edward Carmack, an early 1900s newspaper publisher who hated Ida B. Wells and alcohol and was gunned down on a Nashville street, has been torn down.  There has been a commission in the works for years to replace this with one of Davy Crockett. pic.twitter.com/7xOE5Yhy3n — Natalie Allison (@natalie_allison) May 31, 2020 As night fell, things ratcheted up again, more windows were smashed and a small blaze erupted. A short time later, police with riot gear arrived as a fire burned inside a window at city hall. Officers deployed tear gas as rioters clustered in the center of public square park. "This afternoon’s rally for George Floyd and racial justice was peaceful. I attended and listened," Cooper said on Twitter at 8:22 p.m.. "We cannot let today’s message of reform descend into further violence. If you mean our city harm, go home." At 8:45 p.m., Cooper declared a civil state of emergency and police issued a 10 p.m. curfew. Shortly after 9 p.m. Lee said he was, at Cooper's request, authorizing the National Guard in response to the protests. "The threat to both peace and property is unacceptable and we will work with local law enforcement and community leaders to restore safety and order," Lee tweeted. "This is not a reflection of our state or the fundamental American right to peaceful protest." As the curfew neared, police said anyone outside after 10 p.m. would be arrested. Several downtown storefronts had broken windows. Read or Share this story: https://www.tennessean.com/story/news/crime/2020/05/30/nashville-protests-turn-violent-after-george-floyd-rally-saturday/5295083002/

title: Protesters gather in Murfeesboro to honor George Floyd with vigil
text: Police and protesters met face to face in downtown Murfreesboro and near the Middle Tennessee State University Campus on Sunday night, prompting tear gas and threats of mass arrest that dispersed the crowd before any major violence began. Police said that protesters vandalized an armored vehicle and threw a brick through the window of Whiskey Dix, a local saloon. At one point, officers in gas masks fired tear gas to chase away protesters who were blocking an intersection by lying in the street, said Larry Flowers, a police spokesman. Mayor Shane McFarland enacted a 6:30 p.m. curfew to quell protests, but police struggled to enforce it. Gov. Bill Lee described the events in Murfreesboro as peaceful demonstrations that “escalated to overt threats to public safety and property.” All quiet now. We’re not sitting on the curb just waiting to see if someone will come and talk with us about the events that’s transpired over the last two and a half hours. What a day. pic.twitter.com/uaLCN4F12r — Joe Spears (@joe_spears7) June 1, 2020 At MTSU, a group of about 50 protesters marched towards Forrest Hall – a building named for Ku Klux Klan founder Nathan Bedford Forrest – before being intercepted by police in several armored vehicles. Mikayla Ogletree One local woman, Crystal Mai, said she was driving down East Main when she encountered one of the vehicles, attempted to turn around and her van was struck by tear gas before she could leave. The gas wafted into her van, she said, choking her 12-year-old daughter and two other children. Mai and her daughter stopped by a nearby corner market to buy milk to ease the sting of the tear gas. “They hit my van twice,” Mai said of police. “It busted by her window, and it went straight in.” More from #Murfreesboro. MPD took one person to the ground. Not sure what happened leading to it. pic.twitter.com/kfINxEQ3so — Joe Spears (@joe_spears7) June 1, 2020 Buy Photo Crystal Mai and her 12-year-old daughter, Lariah Daniels, said they were hit by tear gas thrown by police officers in Murfreesboro on May 31, 2020. The pair used milk from a corner store to ease the sting. (Photo: Scott Broden/DNJ) Police and MTSU protesters evenutally negotiated a peace and were seen posing for photos and calming walking off campus together. Andrew Oppmann, an MTSU spokesman, said there was no damage to the school. “Everyone displayed the True Blue spirit that we strive for. The events that have happened are painful, but everyone was calm and peaceful as they conveyed their emotions,” Oppmann said. In downtown Murfreesboro, the meeting between police and protesters was not so amicable. A line of cops, some on horseback, advanced on protesters while threatening mass arrests for violating curfew. Crowds responded by screaming insults and curse words. At one point, officers could be seen tackling a young man of color as the crowd shouted and cars blared their horns in protest. Tempers flared, but the cops ultimately drove the protesters away by about 8:30 p.m., emptying the streets of downtown Murfreesboro. As he drove away one of the lingering groups of protesters, and unidentified sheriff’s deputy could be heard offering an ultimatum: leave or be arrested. “You’re the last ones here,” he told the protesters. “Don’t be the last ones here, because you’ll be the first to be arrested.” Buy Photo The Rutherford County Sheriff's Department uses the mounted patrol to move protesters back from the square and threatened that they will be arrested for breaking curfew after a protest rally held on Murfreesboro's Public Square Sunday, May 31, 2020 in response to the death of George Floyd. (Photo: HELEN COMER/DNJ) The protests in Murfreesboro occurred alongside similar events in cities across the nation, many of which turned to riots and violence. Protests have been spurred by the death of George Floyd, a black man in Minneapolis who died as a police officer pinned him to the ground with a knee on the back of his neck. The killing inflamed long simmering fury over the deaths of people of color at the hands of police. On Saturday, a peaceful rally in Nashville descended into the violence and vandalism, culminating in a small group of rioters lighting a fire inside City Hall. The protests in Murfreesboro began with a peaceful vigil in Public Square intended to honor Floyd’s memory. The event initially drew just 100 people, but quickly grew to fill the square. “Our community has come together in ways I never imagined to stand in solidarity against injustice and overstep of police power," said Mike McDougal, the vigil organizer, during the event. "We must keep this movement growing.” Crowd downtown is in silence for 8 m 46 seconds in memory of how long it took George Floyd to die pic.twitter.com/ZeORfXoG80 — Nancy DeGennaro (@NanDeGennaro) May 31, 2020 Buy Photo Jonathan Dodson works to board up a downtown business on Sunday, May 31, 2020, before a vigil for George Floyd later in the day. (Photo: HELEN COMER/DNJ) Looked like something was thrown at the guy holding the sign. Police quickly come out and break up the crowd. #Murfreesboropic.twitter.com/I8Dwcr6wYT — Joe Spears (@joe_spears7) May 31, 2020 Read or Share this story: https://www.dnj.com/story/news/2020/05/31/murfreesboro-george-floyd-vigil-peaceful-protest/5299427002/

title: Memphis assistant basketball coach Cody Toppert calls inequality 'unconscionable'
text: Memphis assistant basketball coach Cody Toppert joined the growing number of coaches speaking out as the country continues to grapple with widespread unrest in the days following George Floyd’s death. Floyd, a black man, was killed while in police custody on Memorial Day. Memphis experienced four straight nights of largely peaceful demonstrations before tensions escalated between a small group of mostly African-Americans and dozens of officers outfitted in riot gear. The confrontation, which included some bottles thrown at police and at least one firework, resulted in the arrests of five people. The second-year Tigers staff member took to social media Sunday to weigh in. “As a privileged white male working for, working with and coaching some of the most amazing and strong African American men it is absolutely heartbreaking to know the unconscionable inequality that still exists in our world,” Toppert’s statement reads. “As the brother-in-law of an African American deaf man and as the uncle of two African American young adults, I am truly scared for where we are as a society. “But rather than spend time feeling defeated, it is simply time to act, time to walk a path of togetherness, time to use daily actions to snuff out racism and create a world of true equality that will be the foundation for coming generations. We can create the world we want but it will only happen one act at a time. As the stonecutter’s credo says… . When nothing seems to help, I go and look at a stonecutter hammering away at his rock perhaps a hundred times without as much as a crack showing in it. Yet at the hundred-and-first blow, it will split in two, and I know it was not that blow that did it, but all that had gone before. So now is the time to pick up our ‘hammers’ and pound the stone… .” Earlier this week, Memphis forward Lance Thomas spoke out on Twitter in response to Floyd's death. “Not even going to lie I’m never pledging allegiance to the American Flag before any of my games or anywhere I’m at ever again," Thomas wrote on Twitter, as read on air Thursday by Sports 56 radio host Peter Edmiston. "I refuse to pledge allegiance to a country that practices killing black people for sport.” Thomas, a junior forward from Norcross, Georgia, who transferred from Louisville before the 2018-19 season, deleted the tweet on Wednesday. Later, he posted a tweet that read, "made me take it down." Thomas also tweeted an apology "to anyone who took offense to my tweet ... " On Thursday, Memphis athletics director Laird Veatch said he supports Thomas. "I'm looking forward to having conversations with Penny (Hardaway) and possibly Lance directly about it," Veatch said. "I certainly want to be supportive of, first of all, his right to free speech — but, also, the challenges he's going through." Reach sports writer Jason Munz at jason.munz@commercialappeal.com or on Twitter @munzly.

title: Memphis police arrest one after shots fired at police early Sunday
text: Memphis police have arrested one man and are searching for another suspect after shots were fired at police during two separate incidents early Sunday. Police did not say that the shots fired incidents were tied to an earlier peaceful protest Downtown or confrontations between police and protesters near Beale Street after the protest. Martinease Jamison, 39, was arrested in connection to shots that were fired at police in downtown Memphis early Sunday. (Photo: Shelby County Sheriff's Department) MPD said Sunday afternoon that an individual driving near the intersection of Beale Street and Fourth Street fired shots at an officer around 2:30 a.m. The officer was not struck. Martinease Jamison, 39, was arrested and charged with reckless endangerment with a deadly weapon, intentionally evading arrest in an automobile and driving with a revoked or suspended license. He was booked into the Shelby County Jail shortly after noon on Sunday, according to jail records. According to an affidavit, officers were in the entertainment district checking to see if businesses had been vandalized when several vehicles turned eastbound onto Beale Street from Fourth Street. The occupants of the vehicles were shouting obscenities towards the officers. Jamison was driving westbound on Beale but then put his car in reverse and joined the caravan traveling eastbound. Jamison allegedly fired a shot from the vehicle and officers immediately pursued him onto Danny Thomas Boulevard and then onto Martin Luther King Jr. Drive, where a traffic stop was made, according to court documents. Police ordered Jamison to leave the vehicle and saw a black handgun between the driver's seat and the center console. A search warrant was later executed on the vehicle and police recovered a handgun with 15 live rounds in the magazine and one live round in the chamber, according to the affidavit. Jamison told police he did not fire the handgun. At 3:20 a.m., a different individual fired shots at an officer. The individual fled the scene and has not yet been arrested, MPD said. More:Memphis leaders call force used in early morning arrest 'excessive'; MPD says riot gear was worn to protect officers More: Police in riot gear descend on Beale Street after earlier demonstration ended peacefully 7 protesters arrested The two separate shots fired incidents came several hours after a confrontation between a crowd of 100 to 150 people and dozens of riot-gear wearing law enforcement officers, some of whom were on horses. The confrontation started about an hour after the dispersal of a peaceful protest and march through Downtown Memphis that drew about 500 people. Seven other people were arrested Sunday in connection with a confrontation between police and protesters, MPD said. Police released statements about the shots fired incidents and the protesters arrested in the same Facebook post, but none of the protesters have been connected with either shots fired incident. Victoria Jones, 29, was charged with disorderly conduct, rioting and resisting detention. Darin Abston, 28, was charged with disorderly conduct, obstruction of a highway or passageway and resisting detention. Kameron Miller, 19, and Damion Smith, 28, were arrested for disorderly conduct and obstruction of a highway or passageway. Rodney White, 38, and Geno McGary, 27, and Likisha Clark, 33, were arrested for disorderly conduct. This story will be updated as more information becomes available. Corinne Kennedy is a reporter for the Commercial Appeal. She can be reached via email at Corinne.Kennedy@CommercialAppeal.com or on Twitter @CorinneSKennedy Read or Share this story: https://www.commercialappeal.com/story/news/crime/2020/05/31/memphis-police-protests-arrests/5301869002/

title: Gov. Bill Lee mobilizes Tennessee National Guard
text: NASHVILLE, Tenn. — Gov. Bill Lee announced that the Tennessee National Guard will remain mobilized across the state. This announcement follows the riots that took place in Nashville Saturday night, according to a news release from the state. “The right to peaceful protest is foundational to our country, but the violence and vandalism that occurred in Nashville last night was unlawful and tears at the fabric of our community,” said Gov. Lee. “We have reason to believe that many of those involved in unlawful acts are not Tennesseans and we will be working with law enforcement to investigate this further and bring those responsible to justice.” The release says the National Guard will be available to assist state and local law enforcement across all three Grand Divisions. Gov. Lee says he is launching an investigation into riots. To read the news release, click here.

title: In Tennessee, peaceful demonstrations by day turned destructive after dark
text: Thousands in Tennessee massed to protest against police brutality. What carried forth as peaceful demonstrations by day turned destructive in some communities after dark. City sites scorched by arson, historic buildings marred by graffiti and a state of emergency declared by city leaders in response to the unrest. It has left communities across Tennessee shaken, and as tensions mount, it's unclear what's to come. What is certain is residents statewide joined together to scrub graffiti, board up broken windows and sweep shards of glass from the streets as activists and city leaders look for solutions. "There's a historic anger, and there's an historic lack of trust in the community, and right now we need calm, compassionate leadership. We don't need confrontation," said Nashville business owner Tom Morales, who operates Acme Feed & Seed on Broadway where unrest erupted Saturday night. "We cannot ignore what creates the problem. ... I think that a bunch of (instigators) hijacked a positive message." Protests have rippled across the country decrying the brutal force used against George Floyd, a 46-year-old black man who died after a white Minneapolis police officer kept a knee pressed on his neck for more than eight minutes. Demonstrations came to Tennessee on Saturday as peaceful gatherings of hundreds and thousands took place in Nashville, Knoxville, Chattanooga and Jackson. Memphis staged its fourth day of protests. A peaceful protest in front of Jackson City Hall occurred Saturday, May 30, 2020 in the afternoon. The protestors helds signs reading "Black Lives Matter" and “I can’t breathe” after George Floyd's death May 25 in Minneapolis. (Photo: Stephanie Amador / The Jackson Sun) But as dusk fell, what had been nonviolent became tense. "The threat to both peace and property is unacceptable and we will work with local law enforcement and community leaders to restore safety and order," Tennessee Gov. Bill Lee wrote on Twitter. "This is not a reflection of our state or the fundamental American right to peaceful protest." Unrest in Memphis, Chattanooga and Knoxville In Memphis, about two hours after a demonstration against police brutality ended peacefully Saturday, a chaotic few seconds changed the tone. In a dramatic standoff, some people who remained in the crowd of about 60 demonstrators crossed a barricade near the Orpheum Theatre, which was set up to separate protesters from police. When they did, horses holding mounted officers spooked and shuffled. Barricades tumbled to the ground and people fell down. Police moved forward. Glass bottles flew through the air. The unrest marked a shift from the previous days — and that night's earlier events during which demonstrators marched and police largely let demonstrations play out on their own, without interference or arrests. Most of the crowd from Saturday's protest left around 9 p.m. from the National Civil Rights Museum, a short walk from Beale Street. But several dozen stayed. By 11:30 p.m., there were about 35 officers with riot shields, including one armed with a long gun, on the scene near the crowd. stand (Photo: Joe Rondone) A key leader of the earlier protest, DeVante Hill, commented on Twitter: "Tonight just when I thought things were over and we could successfully say we had a peaceful protest, there were young men and women who staggered around near Beale and Main. MPD definitely (incited) them with riot gear, horses and AR-15s ..." "I really believe we can do this. I truly believe we can do this another way. A crowd of 30 staggering people met with intense force like that is just uneasy for not only me to understand but a group of my other white brothers and sisters present as well," Hill wrote. In Chattanooga on Saturday night, overturned trash cans littered the streets as protesters threw rocks and at least one firework, sending others scattering as it exploded. Groups of demonstrators crowded Market Street after midnight, and several arrests were made. A crowd moved quickly through Market Square in Knoxville late Saturday night, smashing windows and destroying planters. Two men were arrested in separate incidents, including a 20-year-old male with six handguns, two shotguns, two rifles and narcotics. In the unrest, activist and former Knoxville City Council candidate David Hayes said on social media that he was shot with pepper-filled balls by police while he was escorting young protesters. Nashville activist: 'The narrative is changing' Nashville, too, saw conflict and destruction erupt in the aftermath of a peaceful protest. The historic Metro Courthouse burned, flames swelling through the first-floor windows. Clouds of tear gas mushroomed across Public Square Plaza. Spray paint tagged the walls. And the granite plaque commemorating Diane Nash, a civil rights leader in Nashville, was broken to pieces — its shards used to shatter windows. It left a mark on a city already scarred by the decimation of deadly tornadoes and the forced isolation of a pandemic. An 8 p.m. curfew was put in place for Nashville on Sunday after Mayor John Cooper, who had earlier Saturday attended the "I Will Breathe" rally to decry police brutality, declared a state of emergency. The order came, even as more demonstrations, including a Sunday vigil honoring Floyd's memory prepared to begin in Murfreesboro. Late morning, several streets leading to the Public Square were blocked by dump trucks and garbage trucks as fencing was set up and business owners preemptively boarded up their windows. "We felt comfortable and knew it would be peaceful," said Scarlett Murphy, who owns Domenico's deli with husband Jeff Murphy. "Then we started getting texts and calls that the people who weren't involved in the peaceful part were also coming, so we decided it would be best to be safe than sorry." At 3:30 p.m., Murfreesboro organizers led a prayer circle where a diverse crowd of approximately 300 people gathered. Attendees chanted, "No justice, no peace," followed by "No racist, no peace," before heading on a march around the square where they continued chanting as they walked. Nashville Mayor John Cooper moves through the crowd gathered Saturday, May 30, 2020, for the “I Will Breathe” rally to protest the death of George Floyd, an unarmed black man who died after being pinned down by a white Minneapolis police officer on Memorial Day. (Photo: Larry McCormack/ The Tennessean) As she reflected on the weekend's events, Odessa Kelly, executive director of activist group Stand Up Nashville, said: "I'm irritated about how the narrative is changing to how people are protesting to what the real problem is." "Rioting is the language of people who feel their voices are never heard. I'm tired of hearing peaceful protests. Do we want that to happen? Yes. But the crux of that is that we have a messed up system here. The police system needs to be fixed to not allow these atrocities to happen." Statewide reporters Yihyun Jeong, Cassandra Stephenson, Kelli Krebs, Chuck Campbell, Allie Clouse, Laura Testino, Desiree Stennett, Daniel Connolly, Corinne S Kennedy, Samuel Hardiman, Nancy DeGennaro, Joseph Spears and Brinley Hineman contributed to this report. Reach Jessica Bliss at 615-259-8253 and jbliss@tennessean.com or on Twitter @jlbliss and please support local journalism. Read or Share this story: https://www.tennessean.com/story/news/2020/05/31/tennessee-peaceful-demonstrations-turn-destructive-after-dark/5299681002/

title: Gov. Lee orders more National Guard members deployed across Tennessee to assist police
text: Faced with the possibility of additional violence, Gov. Bill Lee said Sunday he is increasing a deployment of the Tennessee National Guard to help with law enforcement, this time in all three divisions of the state. The governor made the announcement one day after 75 guardsmen were deployed in Nashville in response to an eruption of violence. The rancor occurred after a peaceful rally attended by thousands of Tennesseans who were protesting police brutality and racism. The governor did not say how many and exactly where the guardsmen will be deployed Sunday. Additionally, Lee announced a joint effort between the Tennessee Bureau of Investigation and local law enforcement to investigate Saturday's violence in Nashville, which he said was provoked by many non-Tennesseans. “The right to peaceful protest is foundational to our country, but the violence and vandalism that occurred in Nashville last night was unlawful and tears at the fabric of our community,” Lee said in a statement. “We have reason to believe that many of those involved in unlawful acts are not Tennesseans and we will be working with law enforcement to investigate this further and bring those responsible to justice.” The violence occurred hours after thousands of people gathered near the Capitol for a peaceful rally, following the death of George Floyd in Minneapolis. Organizers of Saturday's rally urged participants to remain peaceful but violence later erupted throughout the city's downtown area, including windows being smashed and a fire being set at the city's historic Metro Courthouse, which includes city hall offices. In total, 28 Metro Nashville police arrested 28 people Saturday night, many after the 10 p.m. curfew. Of those, 21 are from Nashville, four from elsewhere in Tennessee and three from out of state: Texas, Illinois and New York. Saturday's deployment of the National Guard, which was aimed at providing assistance to the Tennessee Highway Patrol and Metro Police Department, was likely the first such move for law enforcement purposes in decades. The guardsmen first reported to the Capitol grounds, where a statue was toppled over. The troops later moved to Lower Broadway, to provide assistance after businesses were damaged. Metro Nashville Police and protesters scuffle outside Central Precint in Nashville, Tenn., Saturday, May 30, 2020 after the “I Will Breathe” rally to protest the death of George Floyd, an unarmed black man who died after being pinned down by a white Minneapolis police officer on Memorial Day. (Photo: Andrew Nelles / The Tennessean) David Roberson, a spokesman for the Department of General Services, said the extent of damage to state-owned property included graffiti and broken windows and doors. Roberson said windows were broken at the War Memorial building, the Rachel Jackson and Andrew Jackson buildings and Citizens Plaza, where graffiti was also found. A door was broken at the state Supreme Court. Graffiti was found on the Capitol grounds, including on a wall. The toppled statue was to be removed Sunday. Roberson said there are no estimates of the total cost of the various damage to state-owned properties. Lee's deployment of the National Guard came at the request of Nashville Mayor John Cooper, said Laine Arnold, the governor's spokeswoman. The governor made the announcement shortly after 9 p.m. Lee signed an executive order, effectively affirming a 10 p.m. curfew Cooper implemented. "I mobilized the National Guard to assist in protecting the lives and property of Tennesseans, which is a critical responsibility of government," the governor's executive order stated. The governor signed another executive order on Sunday to once again coincide with Nashville's latest curfew, which is set for 8 p.m. Tennessee's last major deployment of its National Guard for law enforcement purposes occurred in 1968, after the assassination of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. As many as 4,000 guardsmen were deployed in Nashville the day King was murdered, according to The Tennessean's archives. Troops were stationed throughout the city, including standing guard, complete with rifles and bayonets, outside the state Capitol. The National Guard was deployed throughout Nashville for several days after King's assassination. Guardsmen were also deployed in Memphis. Reach Joel Ebert at jebert@tennessean.com or 615-772-1681 and on Twitter @joelebert29. Read or Share this story: https://www.tennessean.com/story/news/politics/2020/05/31/national-guard-deployed-saturday-nashville-protest/5299573002/

title: President Trump wants to declare antifa a terrorist group. Here's what we know about their Tennessee activities.
text: President Donald Trump has announced he intends to designate a militant anti-racist movement a terrorist organization as violent protests attended by a variety of activists have erupted in cities around the country, including Nashville. The protests, some of which have resulted in destruction of property and violent clashes with police, are being held in response to police killing George Floyd in Minneapolis and other black individuals who have recently died at the hands of law enforcement. "The United States of America will be designating ANTIFA as a Terrorist Organization," Trump said during remarks at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida on Saturday, though it's unclear by what legal mechanism he can designate a domestic organization to be a terrorist group. Antifa, short for anti-fascist, is a left-wing activist movement active globally, including in Tennessee. The loosely affiliated groups frequently advocate for anti-racist policies, though often take an anarchist and militant approach. There is no formal leadership or unified national structure to the movement. It is not one organization, but rather loose network of activists using a "black bloc" tactic at protests — dressing in all black and concealing their faces with masks and bandannas. Multiple antifa groups have been based in Nashville in recent years. No clear evidence antifa organized violent protests in Nashville While many of the protesters in Nashville on Saturday fit that description, it's unclear if any affiliate with antifa organizations. Metro Nashville Police Department Chief Steve Anderson said Sunday the city is investigating a small group of people they believe used the protest as a cover for violence and other criminal acts. The police chief did not say if any organized groups might be behind the violence in Nashville. A peaceful rally held downtown Saturday afternoon evolved throughout the evening, eventually turning from a march into a chaotic eruption of vandalism to public and private property. Metro Nashville's historic courthouse and city hall were set afire in the process, among other significant damage the building sustained. Antifa groups have, however, openly mobilized overwhelmingly nonviolent counterprotests at events like the October 2017 "White Lives Matter Rally" in Shelbyville and Murfreesboro, as well as made appearances at the annual American Renaissance conference held at Tennessee's Montgomery Bell State Park. The conference, which was canceled this year due to the coronavirus and therefore did not prompt a protest, is held by a white nationalist organization. The protest groups are typically met with a large number of park rangers and forced to demonstrate behind barriers, limiting the possibility for physical confrontations with the conference-goers. While some small altercations have taken place between protesters and counterprotesters at those events, there is no evidence that antifa activists have been responsible for inciting any type of significant violence in Tennessee. They frequently inhabit a very insular online space, trading jabs with individuals they believe to espouse white supremacist beliefs. As with other antifa activists around the nation, Jam City Antifa, a Nashville-based network, has been known to track area white supremacists and post photos and other identifying information about them online, sometimes encouraging followers to show up to heckle them at events. White supremacists have in turn done the same for antifa activists in the area. Last year, U.S. Rep. Tim Burchett, R-Knoxville, filed the "Unmasking Antifa Act," legislation that sought to punish up to 15 years a person wearing a mask or disguise while committing a crime, including threatening or intimidating another individual "exercising their constitutional rights or privileges," according to a statement from Burchett's office at the time. "It’s time we get tough on this issue. These cowards wouldn’t act the way they do if the whole world could see their faces,” Burchett said at the time, which was pre-coronavirus pandemic. Trump's administration quick to cast blame on antifa amid protests U.S. Attorney General William Barr on Sunday also blamed antifa and other similar groups over the violent protests around the country. Barr did not say what specific groups may have been involved or where they came from, but he said the Justice Department and the FBI will work on identifying “criminal organizers and instigators” to be arrested and charged Trump's national security advisor Robert O'Brien told CNN Sunday that the administration planned to "get to the bottom" of antifa's role in the protests. And he said the president and Barr want to know what the FBI is doing to "to track and dismantle and surveil and prosecute antifa." O'Brien denounced "these antifa militant radicals who come into our cities and cross state lines. "They're organized, and use Molotov cocktails and fireworks and gas to burn down our cities, especially businesses in minority neighborhoods. It's got to be stopped," he said on "State of the Union." But some have blamed right-wing provocateurs seeking to incite a race war for the violence. "The truth is nobody really knows," Minnesota Attorney General Keith Ellison said Sunday on NBC News' "Meet the Press." "What the exact political motivation is is unclear at this point. We need to investigate it," Ellison said. USA Today and Adam Tamburin contributed to this report. Reach Natalie Allison at nallison@tennessean.com. Follow her on Twitter at @natalie_allison. Want to read more stories like this? A subscription to one of our Tennessee publications gets you unlimited access to all the latest politics news, podcasts like Grand Divisions, plus newsletters, a personalized mobile experience and the ability to tap into stories, photos and videos from throughout the USA TODAY Network's 261 daily sites.
