The 20-plus minute address was covered live by cable networks and Biden used it to declare, "This job's not about me. It's about you. It's about us." "Look, the presidency is a big job. Nobody will get everything right. And I won't either," Biden said, but promised, "I won't fan the flames of hate." As the former vice president spoke, the National Guard maintained a visible presence to defend public buildings as Philadelphia grapples with sustained violent protests. Several adjacent businesses — banks, convenience stores and hotels were boarded up. A very small audience, including Mayor Jim Kenney, was on hand. Biden is trying to create a stark contrast with Trump, who has embraced the language of confrontation and war, casting himself as the "president of law and order." Trump signaled he would stake his reelection on convincing voters his forceful approach was warranted in a time of national tumult and racial unrest. "I will seek to heal the racial wounds that have long plagued this country – not use them for political gain," Biden said. ___ Catch up on the 2020 election campaign with AP experts on our weekly politics podcast, "Ground Game."

title: George Floyd protests, vigils set for Spring Hill, Franklin, Clarksville Tuesday
text: Police brutality protests and vigils are slated to take place Tuesday in a handful of Middle Tennessee cities including Franklin, Clarksville and Spring Hill. The demonstrations, which broke out in communities across the nation last week, are in response to police killing George Floyd in Minneapolis and other black men and women who have died at the hands of law enforcement. In Nashville Saturday, a peaceful "I Will Breathe" rally in response to Floyd's death was followed by property destruction and clashes between police and some protesters. There will be no citywide curfew in Nashville on Tuesday night, Nashville Mayor John Cooper's office announced. "Yesterday’s peaceful demonstration on the steps of the State Capitol honored our city’s history of non-violent social change," Cooper posted on Twitter. "First responders will maintain a presence to protect residents and property." There will be no citywide curfew tonight in Nashville. Yesterday’s peaceful demonstration on the steps of the State Capitol honored our city’s history of non-violent social change. First responders will maintain a presence to protect residents and property. — Mayor John Cooper (@JohnCooper4Nash) June 2, 2020 On Sunday, a day after a peaceful but angry protest spilled onto the street in Clarksville, Mayor Joe Pitts said he felt a duty to listen after meeting with protesters. Here are list of several of those slated locally today: Clarksville 9 a.m. A Non-Violent Protest for Justice at the Montgomery County Courthouse at 2 Millenium Plaza. Organized by Clarksville CORR (a community-action group). A crowd of around 100 gathered in front of the Montgomery County Courthouse to protest police brutality Tuesday, June 2, 2020 (Photo: Henry Taylor / Leaf Chronicle) Spring Hill Noon A Black Lives Matter assembly will begin at 12 p.m. at the Walgreen’s at 4932 Main St. The local event organizer said the assembly will be one of unifying the community and any violent actions will not be tolerated. The assembly on Main St at Campbell Station Pkwy. has concluded. There were no incidents to report. — Spring Hill Police (@SHPDTN) June 2, 2020 Franklin, Clarksville and Nashville 6 p.m. A Franklin prayer vigil at First Missionary Baptist Church at 113 Natchez Street. The event is called Jesus and Justice. A Franklin prayer vigil at First Missionary Baptist Church at 113 Natchez Street. The event is called Jesus and Justice. 6 p.m. A Clarksville March Against Police Brutality that starts at the Fortera Stadium on Henry Street. Protesters plan to march along 8th Street, College Street, 1st Street and then Commerce Street, then end at the city courthouse. A Clarksville March Against Police Brutality that starts at the Fortera Stadium on Henry Street. Protesters plan to march along 8th Street, College Street, 1st Street and then Commerce Street, then end at the city courthouse. 6 p.m. Mayor John Cooper is slated to join community faith leaders for a vigil to encourage peace and unity. The event will take place on the front lawn of the Historic Metro Courthouse until 6:25 p.m. Check back for updates. Reach Natalie Neysa Alund at nalund@tennessean.com and follow her on Twitter @nataliealund. Read or Share this story: https://www.tennessean.com/story/news/local/2020/06/02/black-lives-matter-protests-tennessee-spring-hill-clarksville/5316911002/

title: #TheShowMustBePaused: Music industry plans blackout Tuesday in response to George Floyd death
text: CLOSE Labels, artists and leading music industry brands say "the show must be paused" for a day of solidarity in response to the death of George Floyd. Many music industry organizations pledge to participate in "Black Out Tuesday" this week, ceasing operations "to disconnect from work and reconnect with our community." Participants show support for the blackout on social media by using the hashtag #TheShowMustBePaused. “As gatekeepers of the culture, it’s our responsibility to not only come together to celebrate the wins, but also hold each other up during a loss," read a social media post shared by many. Floyd, a 46-year-old black man, died last week in Minneapolis after Derek Chauvin, a white police officer, pressed a knee into his neck for more than eight minutes. Floyd's death ignited public unrest for many who believe it to be the latest example of brutal racism shown by police forces. More: Nashville endures decimation, isolation — and now, a peaceful uprising turned destructive Blackout Tuesday 2020: Participants urged to not use Black Lives Matter hashtags Protests, some escalating with physical injury and property damage, swept through major cities last week after Floyd's death, including Nashville, Murfreesboro and Memphis. Music Row labels such as Warner Music Nashville, Big Machine Label Group, Big Loud, Universal Nashville, Sony Music Nashville, Curb Records and others will participate in "Black Out Tuesday" and many are urging followers to support the Black Lives Matter movement and "Justice for George Floyd" petition at change.org. Live Nation, ASCAP and Amazon Music join organizations with a Nashville footprint in the blackout. In coordination with the blackout, Middle Tennessee State University hosts virtual panel Tuesday called “Being African-American in the Nashville Music Industry." The discussion features country recording artist Mickey Guyton and Grammy Award-winning producer Shannon Sanders. The free panel can be viewed via Zoom at 2 p.m. Interested individuals can RSVP online in advance. “Many of us are devastated and want to help, but we aren’t sure how," Beverly Keel, dean of MTSU College of Media and Entertainment, said in a news release. "We want to do the right thing and we certainly don’t want to say or do the wrong thing. This event is designed to educate and enlighten attendees and then offers tips on how they can become a better advocate and ally of people of color.” 'The long haul' Music industry professionals Jamila Thomas and Brianna Agyemang launched #TheShowMustBePaused initiative with plans to "be in this fight for the long haul," per to theshowmustbepaused.com. "The music industry is a multi-billion dollar industry," read a letter penned to the website. "An industry that has profited predominantly from black art. Our mission is to hold the industry at large, including major corporations (plus) their partners who benefit from the efforts, struggles and successes of black people accountable." And a number of Nashville artists pledged participation. Rock musician Lzzy Hale of Halestorm, country singer Lindsay Ell and songwriter Brandy Clark were among those to share #TheShowMustBePaused. "We are all created equal," Ell shared. "Every single one of us." She continued, "I will be spending (Tuesday) learning how to continue to take a stand and use my voice to fight for justice, peace & reconciliation." We are all created equal. Every single one of us. There will be no Living wEll episode this Tuesday. I will be spending it learning how to continue to take a stand and use my voice to fight for justice, peace & reconciliation. #theshowmustbepaused#blackouttuesdaypic.twitter.com/nFBou5AiHD — Lindsay Ell (@lindsayell) June 1, 2020 Brandi Carlile, a leading voice in Americana music, said Sunday via Instagram that she's in "complete support of" the Tuesday silence. "I know that I intend to be in compliance with and observe that," Carlile said, "so do many of my friends." 'Churns my stomach' As some top entertainers in Nashville remain silent, others join in calling for immediate change — sharing frustration and grief for ongoing racial injustice. Country-pop act Dan + Shay shared that "we, as humans, must come together to make a change." On Facebook, Tim McGraw wrote that "We must find a way to shine light on what is happening. Find a way to talk. Find a way to understand." "This Is Us" singer Jimmie Allen wrote that he challenges "everyone to love each other and let our hearts speak louder than the injustice." Allen's post read, "As a black man and a father raising a black boy, I'm worried. The uncertainty of his safety churns my stomach." Kacey Musgraves posted resources for her followers to support Floyd and Black Lives Matter, writing, "White people have had it so ... wrong since the beginning and I will do whatever I can (to) help break the disgusting, damaging cycle racism and systemic privilege causes." Rock band Paramore donated $25,000 to be split between Black Lives Matter Nashville, Campaign Zero and the American Civil Liberties Union. "These contributions are in addition to our commitment to be vigilant, and be responsible with our privilege," the band shared. And Margo Price shared that she won't be live streaming or sharing promotional content through June 7 "out of solidarity with the black community (and) to challenge my own white privilege." "I will be using my voice solely to bring light to the the tragedy and suffering of the [Black, Indigenous, People of Color]," Price wrote. In solidarity with the black community, & to challenge my own white privilege, I will not be playing live streams nor will I be sharing my own content from now til June 7. I will be using my voice solely to bring light to the the tragedy and suffering of the #BIPOCpic.twitter.com/eJ65cfs7Il — Margo Price (@MissMargoPrice) June 1, 2020 Read or Share this story: https://www.tennessean.com/story/entertainment/music/2020/06/01/black-out-tuesday-music-industry-george-floyd-death-theshowmustbepaused/5306880002/

title: Past pandemics in Knoxville have led to stark political choices — with deadly consequences
text: COVID-19 is not Knoxville's first pandemic. From smallpox to yellow fever, pandemics have periodically emerged in the city and surrounding country. Cholera struck Knoxville at least three times. Epidemiologists are fond of saying “if you’ve seen a pandemic you have seen one pandemic.” Outbreaks can’t necessarily be compared directly because each disease behaves differently. But choices made by leaders during these outbreaks are comparable. Knoxville's history tells us that leaders can fail to adapt to rapidly evolving pandemics and allow preconceptions to narrow their vision. “Pandemics catch people off guard,” said Susan Lawrence, a medical history professor at the University of Tennessee, Knoxville. “They are a crisis by definition, something that people don’t plan for well.” We mined historic news articles and conducted interviews to find out how Knox County handled outbreaks in the past. Indeed, every outbreak was different. Slowing the spread of Spanish flu In 1918 when Knoxville-based soldiers first started coming down with pandemic flu, local health authorities did not take it seriously. It was the height of World War I and main vectors of the 1918-1919 influenza pandemic, otherwise known as the Spanish Flu, was actually attributed to movement of American soldiers. Coverage of the Spanish Flu pandemic in the Oct. 19, 1918 issue of the Nashville Tennessean. (Photo: Nashville Tennessean) "They'd come here on the railroad, get off the station on North Gay Street, right in the middle of town," said Laura Still, a local historian and tour guide with the Knoxville History Project. Before COVID-19, Still produced a lecture on local epidemics. These soldiers trained at a base in Chilhowee Park and on the University of Tennessee campus mingled freely in town. What started as a few cases quickly grew. Before long, hospitals were overrun. On Oct.9, Dr. W.R. Cochrane, secretary of the Knoxville Board of Health at the time, took action. Still explained that Cochrane ordered entertainment venues, schools and churches to close. People wore masks in public. Street cars were sterilized. Knoxvillians were encouraged to wash their hands and cover their mouths when they coughed. The police enforced a ban on spitting and publicly lectured people who broke protocols. "They'd patrol neighborhoods and lecture people who were out there. Just embarrass the heck out of them." Still said. Coverage of the Spanish Flu pandemic in the Jan. 28, 1920 issue of the Nashville Tennessean. (Photo: Nashville Tennessean) Red Cross nurses wearing face masks escorted soldiers off the train to Chillhowee Park where they were quarantined. Concerned citizens went door to door in the countryside looking for stricken families too sick to care for themselves. The public health measures were enforced until the disease burnt itself out and the public did not protest. The mayor took a back seat to the Board of Health. There was no second wave. But there was one exception to all of these closures - a World War I public war bond auction. Dr. Cochrane, in true wartime spirit, allowed “patriotic” events to continue. At the time, there were over 1,000 cases of pandemic flu in Knoxville. The auction turned into a festival on Gay Street, complete with street performers and music. Thousands of people — young and old, black and white, solider and civilian — were in attendance. Local historian Jack Neely wryly notes, "As the numbers in the coming days would suggest, patriotism was no protection from the Spanish Flu." In the weeks after the Liberty Bond Fair, the number of infected would quadruple. By the end of that month, over 10,000 Knoxvillians came down with flu. That's in a city that was, at that time, between 75,000-85,000 people. Parallels to today In many ways, the situation in 1918 is different in Knoxville than it is now. America's economy was propped up by wartime production, meaning pandemic flu did not cause the mass unemployment we're seeing with COVID-19. People were already operating in a wartime frame on the homefront so they complied with government orders. But like pandemic flu, local leaders during the COVID-19 pandemic are left to decide how to act themselves. During the 1918 pandemic, there was no central public health authority like the Centers for Disease Control. Now, the Trump administration has in many ways punted responsibility for COVID-19 to the states. In Tennessee, this means that decision-making power is even more localized due to the patchwork of metro health departments like the Knox County Health Department. How we will fare in the coming months depends on our ability to respond to the evidence in front of us, to align political will with public health. There is ample historical precedence for this beyond Knoxville. Historical cholera, typhus, HIV outbreaks around the world During the 1892 cholera outbreak in Hamburg, Germany, city leaders actively opposed the installation of municipal water filters by Robert Koch, the father of germ theory. They believed state-run sanitation measures were an assault on local autonomy and a threat to the shipping industry. Thousands died while they promoted the "miasma theory" of disease as political cover. In the middle of a devastating typhus epidemic in a Prussian-occupied region of Poland, the Prussian government fired medical pioneer and "father of pathology" Rudolf Virchow rather than implement any of the sanitation or antipoverty policies he recommended. Virchow identified the squalor, malnutrition and poverty of the Polish people of the region as major factors in the epidemic. He called the epidemic a "scandal that has become full-blown by the death of thousands." His prescriptions went beyond the medical and into the political. Virchow would go on to write that “medicine is a social science and politics is nothing more than medicine in larger scale.” This pattern of intractability during epidemics is not borne out of scientific ignorance but politics. It is impossible, for example, to reckon with the HIV pandemic without considering the politics of the Reagan administration. Centers for Disease Control epidemiologist Dr. Don Francis said in an interview with "Frontline," that early in the HIV pandemic the direction from the White House was to “look pretty and do as little as you can.” It was clearly a political nonstarter. A 1918 story in the Nashville Banner details the impact of flu on Tennessee. (Photo: University of Michigan Center for the History of Medicine Influenza Encyclopedia) By the end of the 1980s, over 85,000 Americans would die of complications from HIV. Not every political reaction is negative. Sometimes politics aligns with public health. The global collaboration of doctors, governments and humanitarians led by the WHO that eliminated smallpox was a political project as much as it was a scientific one. Public pressure on governments can create the political climate for this kind of realignment to happen. During the HIV pandemic, protesters took over the Food and Drug Administration demanding government action on HIV and a reform of how medical trials are conducted. Those reforms persist to this day. When doctors and leaders get it wrong In 1873, Knoxville was struck by a deadly epidemic of cholera. The first recorded case was a man in his fifties. He was brought to a local doctor with severe vomiting on a June evening. By midnight he had died. Knoxville health officer at that time, Dr. F. K Bailey, wrote in his logs that this was a typical case. The unnamed patient was described as “imprudent in all habits.” In Dr. Baily’s account, the man said to have eaten vegetables “with impunity” and drank whisky daily. At the time, many doctors believed that cholera was a disease of excess, caused by eating too many vegetables, fruits, ice cream or drinking too much alcohol. Consequentially, watermelons and ice cream sales were banned in the city. "They were still blaming contraband watermelons and people smuggling contraband watermelons." said Still, "People were made to feel it was their fault if they got sick." Contrary to the conventional wisdom of the 1870s, cholera does not spread that way. Vibrio cholera, the bacterium that causes the disease, does not care about the supposed moral failing of eating too much watermelon. Cholera causes vomiting and diarrhea not to punish gluttons but so that it will more easily spread to new hosts. It moves through contaminated waterways, killing thousands. This 1939 Nashville Banner article discusses the 1873 cholera epidemic that killed about 1,000 in one summer. (Photo: Courtesy of Tennessee State Library & Archives) In 1873, germ theory was still relatively new. Many doctors had probably heard of it but not everyone was on board. Robert Koch, the father of germ theory, would not figure out that cholera was caused by bacteria for another decade. But in Knoxville, people were dying. The disease was spreading along the low-lying areas near First and Second Creeks. The Bottoms, a predominantly African-American neighborhood at what now is the James White Parkway, was particularly hard hit. The ordinances outlawing melons were not clearly working. Toward the end of August, Dr. Bailey himself fell ill. He recovered, and the affair may have influenced his thinking. "He suddenly realized he didn't have to have bad morals to get cholera." said Still. She explained that Dr. Bailey's notes revealed his prejudices but by the end there was a remarkable shift in attitude toward poorer patients he takes more note of their living conditions. "He starts to realize somehow the water source is the problem." Dr. Bailey was vested with nearly unlimited authority on “sanitary measures.” After he fell ill, he used those powers to sterilize local creeks, outhouses and springs with iron sulphate. He ordered ditches and puddles drained and treated with lime. Old, leaky outhouses were sterilized, demolished, buried and replaced. Dr. Bailey enlisted police officers to check cases and assure cleanup. The epidemic abated shortly afterward. There's a broad lesson to Knoxville's third cholera outbreak. The politics of disease can interfere with the public health response. Standard wisdom essentially blamed the poor for their own illness by making it a moral failing. Dr. Bailey was unable intervene effectively until he discarded this ideological baggage. What it means today and into the future It’s fair to argue that Knoxville and Knox County have done comparatively well in getting ahead of our current pandemic. That’s especially when measured against local historical reactions to outbreaks. By acting before hospitals were overwhelmed, we may have avoided a worst-case scenario. The Knoxville-Knox County Phased Reopening Plan grants local leaders substantial flexibility in responding to the pandemic. However, there is clear political pressure for reopening quickly. But history is clear: You cannot cheat a pandemic. While there are many things local authorities cannot control, like test kit shortages, they can and do respond to the evidence in front of them. In 1918 it was understood that pandemic flu spread through crowds and barring a disastrous exception, crowds were forbidden from gathering. By the end of the 1873 cholera breakout, health officials knew the disease spread through the water so they did what they could to clean up. History shows that in order to deal with a pandemic and save lives, all local officials must act on the best available scientific evidence. Email Vincent Gabrielle at vincent.gabrielle@knoxnews.com and follow him on Twitter @vincentdgabriel. If you enjoy Vincent’s coverage, support strong local journalism by subscribing for full access to all our content on every platform. title: Exclusive: Nashville police looking for 20-30 people they say drove violence during Saturday protest
text: On Sunday, as the city confronted shattered remnants of a peaceful protest overtaken by violence, Nashville police tried to identify 20-30 people they said hijacked the demonstration and used it “as a cover for the destruction they wanted to employ.” Police Chief Steve Anderson said the vast majority of more than 1,000 protesters at a Saturday demonstration against police brutality and racism remained peaceful. Video footage from the Central Precinct and the Metro Courthouse in downtown Nashville showed isolated agitators leading the violence, destruction and arson. Photos and video from the Nashvilleprotest showed people dressed in all black with backpacks moving through the crowd that gathered to protest the death of George Floyd, a 46-year-old black man who died in Minneapolis after a white police officer kneeled on his neck for more than eight minutes. Other photos show unidentified individuals breaking windows and starting fires inside the Metro Courthouse. Many of the people seen vandalizing buildings appeared to be white. Metro Nashville Police try to get past protesters outside the Central Precinct in Nashville, Tenn., Saturday, May 30, 2020 after the “I Will Breathe” rally to protest the death of George Floyd, an unarmed black man who died after being pinned down by a white Minneapolis police officer on Memorial Day. (Photo: Andrew Nelles / The Tennessean) Anderson said police detectives were working to identify the people they believed to be insurgents. Police are establishing a dedicated email to collect tips about the protest. People can send information, photos and videos to NashvilleArsonInvestigation2020@nashville.gov. Anderson did not know if any of the isolated agitators were among the 28 people arrested during and after the protest. Most of the people taken into custody Saturday were charged with relatively minor misdemeanor violations such as disorderly conduct. None are charged in connection with the arson at the courthouse. Eleven of the arrestees were white. Sixteen were black. Three had out-of-state addresses, according to police. Gov. Bill Lee on Sunday said state authorities had "reason to believe that many of those involved in unlawful acts are not Tennesseans." The state Department of Safety and Homeland Security is launching an investigation into the matter along with the Tennessee Bureau of Investigation and other agencies. President Donald Trump on Sunday connected left-wing activist movement antifa with violence overtaking protests in multiple cities. In a tweet, he said the United States government would label the group a terrorist organization. Antifa, short for anti-fascist, is active globally, including in Tennessee. The loosely affiliated groups frequently advocate for anti-racist policies, though often via an anarchist and militant approach. The police chief did not say if organized groups might have been behind the violence in Nashville. Spokesman Don Aaron said police suspected antifa and white supremacist groups could have been involved, although he said it was too soon to know for sure. Local prosecutors are working with police as the investigation moves forward. “We have a lot of work to do to identify individuals and determine their motives,” Nashville District Attorney Glenn Funk said. “Arson is a very serious crime.” Police also are collaborating with federal authorities as they continue to investigate. U.S. Attorney Don Cochran, who handles federal prosecutions in Middle Tennessee, met with officers Saturday. The feds are focusing on anyone who might have crossed state lines to participate in violent protests. Demonstration mirrored peaceful protests for most of the day Nashville, a hub of the civil rights movement of the 1960s, has seen a wave of protests over the past few years as activists spoke out against police officers killing black people — nationwide and here at home. Anderson said much of Saturday's demonstration, which began with a rally at Legislative Plaza and continued with a march through the city, mirrored peaceful Black Lives Matter protests in the past. Protesters have called police violence an outgrowth of systemic racism embedded in many facets of policing and American life. When protesters took to Nashville streets in 2014 after a police officer fatally shot Michael Brown in Ferguson, Missouri, local police officers handed out hot chocolate and set up rolling roadblocks. Protests bubbled up again in 2018 after white Nashville police officer Andrew Delke, 26, shot and killed Daniel Hambrick, who was black, as he was running away during a foot pursuit. Those protests remained largely peaceful. “Every previous march we’ve had, for the very most part, was people trying to express their thoughts, their ideas,” Anderson said. “That’s exactly what they did yesterday. But there was an element in the crowd that had other thoughts in mind." Protesters stand in Legislative Plaza in Nashville, Tenn., Saturday, May 30, 2020 for the “I Will Breathe” rally to protest the death of George Floyd, an unarmed black man who died after being pinned down by a white Minneapolis police officer on Memorial Day. (Photo: Larry McCormack/ The Tennessean) When chaos erupted, Anderson said, “only a small number were actually involved in defacing, setting fires, breaking windows or damaging cars.” “This was a peaceful gathering, a very peaceful march through downtown," Anderson said. “Then people within that group, using it as a cover, became the criminals that we’re seeking to identify at this point." Lee called in the National Guard to assist police at Mayor John Cooper's request. State forces are expected to continue collaborating with local law enforcement moving forward. Anderson believed the "attack on the courthouse," which included multiple fires, break-ins and vandalism, was premeditated. “That was a planned attack,” he said. “There was an organized effort and then they may have gathered up a following as they went along." Police wearing riot gear lined the courthouse after fires became visible, lobbing cans of tear gas into the crowd and asking demonstrators to disperse. “It wasn’t until the arson attack on the courthouse that I authorized chemical spray," Anderson said. “When there’s a fire we've got to get the fire department in there and they’ve got to be safe.” Anderson said a heightened police presence would be planned downtown in the coming days. Activists at the heart of the peaceful rally and march said their message should not be lost while law enforcement pieces together the details of the day. They said the Community Oversight Board, a civilian panel that investigates allegations of police misconduct, should be further empowered to root out corruption in the police department. Organizers have criticized Anderson and the police department for failing to cooperate with the board. Progress will require more commitment to and investment in institutions focused on eliminating racism and discrimination at every level of government, said Jamel Campbell-Gooch, deputy director of the nonprofit Gideon’s Army and vice chair of the Community Oversight Board. “There are things we can be reaching for locally right now,” Campbell-Gooch said. “It’s time. All the changes they want to see needs to be invested by the mayor’s office to actually stop violence.” Yihyun Jeong and Natalie Allison contributed to this report. Reach Adam Tamburin at 615-726-5986 and atamburin@tennessean.com. Follow him on Twitter @tamburintweets. Read or Share this story: https://www.tennessean.com/story/news/local/2020/05/31/nashville-police-violent-agitators-saturday-protest/5300173002/

title: #TheShowMustBePaused: Music industry plans blackout Tuesday in response to George Floyd death
text: CLOSE Labels, artists and leading music industry brands say "the show must be paused" for a day of solidarity in response to the death of George Floyd. Many music industry organizations pledge to participate in "Black Out Tuesday" this week, ceasing operations "to disconnect from work and reconnect with our community." Participants show support for the blackout on social media by using the hashtag #TheShowMustBePaused. “As gatekeepers of the culture, it’s our responsibility to not only come together to celebrate the wins, but also hold each other up during a loss," read a social media post shared by many. Floyd, a 46-year-old black man, died last week in Minneapolis after Derek Chauvin, a white police officer, pressed a knee into his neck for more than eight minutes. Floyd's death ignited public unrest for many who believe it to be the latest example of brutal racism shown by police forces. More: Nashville endures decimation, isolation — and now, a peaceful uprising turned destructive Blackout Tuesday 2020: Participants urged to not use Black Lives Matter hashtags Protests, some escalating with physical injury and property damage, swept through major cities last week after Floyd's death, including Nashville, Murfreesboro and Memphis. Music Row labels such as Warner Music Nashville, Big Machine Label Group, Big Loud, Universal Nashville, Sony Music Nashville, Curb Records and others will participate in "Black Out Tuesday" and many are urging followers to support the Black Lives Matter movement and "Justice for George Floyd" petition at change.org. Live Nation, ASCAP and Amazon Music join organizations with a Nashville footprint in the blackout. In coordination with the blackout, Middle Tennessee State University hosts virtual panel Tuesday called “Being African-American in the Nashville Music Industry." The discussion features country recording artist Mickey Guyton and Grammy Award-winning producer Shannon Sanders. The free panel can be viewed via Zoom at 2 p.m. Interested individuals can RSVP online in advance. “Many of us are devastated and want to help, but we aren’t sure how," Beverly Keel, dean of MTSU College of Media and Entertainment, said in a news release. "We want to do the right thing and we certainly don’t want to say or do the wrong thing. This event is designed to educate and enlighten attendees and then offers tips on how they can become a better advocate and ally of people of color.” 'The long haul' Music industry professionals Jamila Thomas and Brianna Agyemang launched #TheShowMustBePaused initiative with plans to "be in this fight for the long haul," per to theshowmustbepaused.com. "The music industry is a multi-billion dollar industry," read a letter penned to the website. "An industry that has profited predominantly from black art. Our mission is to hold the industry at large, including major corporations (plus) their partners who benefit from the efforts, struggles and successes of black people accountable." And a number of Nashville artists pledged participation. Rock musician Lzzy Hale of Halestorm, country singer Lindsay Ell and songwriter Brandy Clark were among those to share #TheShowMustBePaused. "We are all created equal," Ell shared. "Every single one of us." She continued, "I will be spending (Tuesday) learning how to continue to take a stand and use my voice to fight for justice, peace & reconciliation." We are all created equal. Every single one of us. There will be no Living wEll episode this Tuesday. I will be spending it learning how to continue to take a stand and use my voice to fight for justice, peace & reconciliation. #theshowmustbepaused#blackouttuesdaypic.twitter.com/nFBou5AiHD — Lindsay Ell (@lindsayell) June 1, 2020 Brandi Carlile, a leading voice in Americana music, said Sunday via Instagram that she's in "complete support of" the Tuesday silence. "I know that I intend to be in compliance with and observe that," Carlile said, "so do many of my friends." 'Churns my stomach' As some top entertainers in Nashville remain silent, others join in calling for immediate change — sharing frustration and grief for ongoing racial injustice. Country-pop act Dan + Shay shared that "we, as humans, must come together to make a change." On Facebook, Tim McGraw wrote that "We must find a way to shine light on what is happening. Find a way to talk. Find a way to understand." "This Is Us" singer Jimmie Allen wrote that he challenges "everyone to love each other and let our hearts speak louder than the injustice." Allen's post read, "As a black man and a father raising a black boy, I'm worried. The uncertainty of his safety churns my stomach." Kacey Musgraves posted resources for her followers to support Floyd and Black Lives Matter, writing, "White people have had it so ... wrong since the beginning and I will do whatever I can (to) help break the disgusting, damaging cycle racism and systemic privilege causes." Rock band Paramore donated $25,000 to be split between Black Lives Matter Nashville, Campaign Zero and the American Civil Liberties Union. "These contributions are in addition to our commitment to be vigilant, and be responsible with our privilege," the band shared. And Margo Price shared that she won't be live streaming or sharing promotional content through June 7 "out of solidarity with the black community (and) to challenge my own white privilege." "I will be using my voice solely to bring light to the the tragedy and suffering of the [Black, Indigenous, People of Color]," Price wrote. In solidarity with the black community, & to challenge my own white privilege, I will not be playing live streams nor will I be sharing my own content from now til June 7. I will be using my voice solely to bring light to the the tragedy and suffering of the #BIPOCpic.twitter.com/eJ65cfs7Il — Margo Price (@MissMargoPrice) June 1, 2020 Read or Share this story: https://www.tennessean.com/story/entertainment/music/2020/06/01/black-out-tuesday-music-industry-george-floyd-death-theshowmustbepaused/5306880002/

title: Past pandemics in Knoxville have led to stark political choices — with deadly consequences
text: COVID-19 is not Knoxville's first pandemic. From smallpox to yellow fever, pandemics have periodically emerged in the city and surrounding country. By the end of the 1873 cholera breakout, health officials knew the disease spread through the water so they did what they could to clean up. History shows that in order to deal with a pandemic and save lives, all local officials must act on the best available scientific evidence. Email Vincent Gabrielle at vincent.gabrielle@knoxnews.com and follow him on Twitter @vincentdgabriel. If you enjoy Vincent’s coverage, support strong local journalism by subscribing for full access to all our content on every platform. title: Tear gas flies as Minneapolis rioters protest death of George Floyd in police custody
text: Masked vandals smashed windows, slashed police car tires and threw bricks in a standoff that lasted until 5:00 a.m. The Minneapolis Police Department fired four police officers who arrested Floyd. The 46-year-old died after anofficer pinned him down by the neck with one knee. MINNEAPOLIS—Protests turned violent on Tuesday as anti-police activists smashed windows and vandalized police cars in response to the death of an African American man at the hands of four law enforcement officers. George Floyd died Monday after his arrest outside Cup Foods, a Minneapolis restaurant that reported a customer who paid for a meal with a counterfeit $20 bill. Widely circulated videos of the incident show a handcuffed Floyd on the ground with a white officer’s knee on the back of his neck, his pleas for help ignored. “I can’t breathe,” Floyd told the officer. The 46-year-old man died later at the Hennepin County Medical Center. Thousands of protesters descended on a police precinct a day later. Some spray-painted patrol cars, slashed tires and broke windows. During a protest over the police killing of George Floyd, protesters gather in the back of the precinct where some of the protesters picked up rocks and medal objects to smash the windows of a squad car in the back on May 26, 2020. (Chris Juhn/Zenger) A protester throws a gas canister back at police during a protest over the killing of George Floyd in Minneapolis on May 26, 2020. (Chris Juhn/Zenger) Police responded with tear gas canisters after the crowd broke through the gate that protected more vehicles. The standoff lasted until 5:00 a.m., with demonstrators hurling bricks and other objects at police. Protesters had walked more than 2 miles from Cup Foods, organized by activists who would later try to keep the march peaceful. Minneapolis Police Chief Medaria Arradondo fired Officer Derek Chauvin and three other officers who were present. “Being black in America should not be a death sentence. This officer failed in the most basic human sense,” Minneapolis Mayor Jacob Frey said in a press conference. Thousands of protesters march down Hiawatha Ave in Minneapolis to protest the police killing of George Floyd by the Minneapolis police on May 26, 2020. (Chris Juhn/Zenger) Protesters set up shopping carts from Target to defend against rubber bullets and other projectiles during a protest over the police killing of George Floyd in Minneapolis on May 26, 2020. (Chris Juhn/Zenger) Police stand guard in front of the 3rd police precinct in Minneapolis as they are lit from the neon sign of Hiawatha Lake Wine & Spirits. Protesters gathered at the precinct to protest the police killing of George Floyd on May 26, 2020. (Chris Juhn/Zenger) “Four responding MPD officers involved in the death of George Floyd have been terminated. This is the right call,” Frey tweeted. Nekima Levy-Armstrong, a community organizer, first called for a protest on Facebook. “Friends, Please wear your masks and join us if you can in demanding justice for the Black man who was unjustly killed by Minneapolis Police yesterday in broad daylight,” she wrote. “We can’t escape police violence even in a global pandemic.”

title: Fires blaze and looters rampage during second night of Minneapolis anti-police protests following black man’s death
text: Smoke billowed high over Minneapolis on Wednesday night as anti-police protesters vented their anger over a black man’s death with looting and arson. Video by Chris Juhn/Zenger The previous night had seen mostly peaceful protests that drew an estimated 4,000 people to the streets. Looters emptied a liquor store, and tear gas canisters flew as demonstrators broke squad car windows. Twenty-four hours later furious orange flames pockmarked the city blocks surrounding the Third Police Precinct where Officer Derek Chauvin was based. The white patrolman killed George Floyd, a black man, during an arrest Monday night over an accusation of retail forgery. Chauvin was a 19-year police veteran whose career has been pockmarked with other allegations of excessive force including three shootings. One was fatal. As his past percolated through local and national news media, the protests turned more violent. Fires consumed an auto parts store, a Wendy’s restaurants and an affordable housing complex that was expected to house hundreds. Sprinkler systems saved at least two grocery stores from burning to the ground, but other businesses were at the mercy of the flames. Looters stripped bare what wasn’t consumed by fire, laying waste to both corner shope and cavernous Target stores. Reports circulated of business owners pacing rooftops with loaded shotguns. Widely seen video footage showed Chauvin kneeling on the 46-year-old Floyd’s neck for nearly nine minutes as he complained that he couldn’t breathe and pleaded for his life. Floyd lost consciousness at the scene, and was pronounced dead at a nearby hospital. The FBI and law enforcement agencies in Minnesota have launched investigations. The city of Minneapolis fired Chauvin and three other officers. Mayor Jacob Frey called for criminal charges on Wednesday, hours before the riots escalated. “Why is the man who killed George Floyd not in jail?” he asked. “We cannot turn a blind eye. It is on us as leaders to see this for what it is and call it what it is.” Some protesters made their way to Chauvin’s home on Wednesday, scrawling the word “murderer” on his driveway in chalk. Others wrote “I can’t breathe” in red spray paint, the words Floyd is heard saying on the video of his last conscious moments.

title: Asheville protests: Second day started peacefully, ended with more destruction and gun shots
text: ASHEVILLE — Protests and destruction grew on a second night of demonstrations downtown with hundreds facing off June 1 with police decrying what prosecutors say was the murder of black Minneapolis resident George Floyd by one of that city's police officers. The first night of demonstrations in Asheville on Sunday caused the shutdown of interstate traffic, but were less violent and destructive than many other protests happening around the nation that have included the shooting of officers and at least one death. On Monday night, Asheville protesters did not march but the intensity ramped up with guns brandished and fired and more property damage near the city center. Monday night, other law enforcement agencies, including North Carolina State Troopers, stood in a line outside of the department, facing protesters who were chanting "black lives matter" and asking police to take a knee. More: Asheville police ask other agencies for help prior to Monday protest But after hours of peaceful protest, the night ended in a series of tear gas canisters and eventually gunfire. This is the second consecutive night that protesters in Asheville have been met with tear gas. On Sunday, what protester Maria Norris described as a friendly march escorted by police turned when the protesters walked onto the Jeff Bowen bridge. At that point, police used the tear gas without first telling protesters to disperse, Norris said. As the peaceful protest deteriorated on Monday, the confederate monument dedicated to Zebulon Vance was vandalized. More: Why did Asheville officers first fire tear gas at protest? Participants say they were peaceful Hours before the protest began, President Donald Trump used federal troops to forcibly remove protesters from a church near the White House as he gave a speech declaring himself the “president of law and order.” Earlier in the day, the Hennepin (Minnesota) County Medical Examiner ruled Floyd’s death a homicide and that his heart stopped while he was restrained by officers with a knee on his neck. Video of the arrest has caused nationwide unrest that has inspired protests nationwide. Read or Share this story: https://www.knoxnews.com/story/news/2020/06/02/asheville-protest-crowd-gathers-downtown-june-1-2nd-night/3124181001/

title: Police arrest 11 at overnight protest in Johnson City
text: Ten were charged with disorderly conduct and blocking lanes of travel. One was additionally charged with unlawful possession of a handgun and served with warrants charging him with aggravated robbery and contributing to the delinquency of a minor. Nine of the 11 arrested were listed as residing in the Tri-Cities area. All of them were Tennessee residents. Those arrested were: — Devin Absher, 23, Seymour, Tenn. — Elizabeth Allen, 18, Elizabethton — Katlyn Ayers, 20, Jonesborough — Dezmond Carpenter, 20, Johnson City — Benjamin Flanary, 34, Kingsport — Wesley Frost, 29, Johnson City — Jayden Jennings, 19, Kingsport — Katlyn Kreisa, 19, Elizabethton — Naythan Matherly, 19, Jonesborough — Frederick Psioda, 19, Johnson City — Morgan Roberts, Silver Point, Tenn. They were arrested early Tuesday after hours of peaceful protesting turned tense, when protesters refused officers’ orders to move from the intersection of West State of Franklin Road and University Parkway. City officers, Washington County sheriff’s deputies, Greeneville City officers and state police advanced on the protesters to make arrests and donned gas masks to suggest the use of tear gas. In the Johnson City Police Department narrative included with the arrest report, written by officer F. Holder, he wrote protesters continued to block the lanes after police asked them multiple times to move to the sidewalk. Carpenter was charged with the weapon violation when an employee at the Washington County Detention Center reported finding a loaded .40-caliber pistol in his backpack. According to the report, he does not have a valid handgun carry permit. Officers also said they found an outstanding arrest warrants for him charging him with aggravated burglary and contributing to the delinquency of a minor. Before noon, one online fundraiser to provide bail for those arrested had raised more than $8,000. The arrested protesters were reportedly released Tuesday.

title: George Floyd protests, vigils set for Spring Hill, Franklin, Clarksville Tuesday
text: Police brutality protests and vigils are slated to take place Tuesday in a handful of Middle Tennessee cities including Franklin, Clarksville and Spring Hill. The demonstrations, which broke out in communities across the nation last week, are in response to police killing George Floyd in Minneapolis and other black men and women who have died at the hands of law enforcement. In Nashville Saturday, a peaceful "I Will Breathe" rally in response to Floyd's death was followed by property destruction and clashes between police and some protesters. There will be no citywide curfew in Nashville on Tuesday night, Nashville Mayor John Cooper's office announced. "Yesterday’s peaceful demonstration on the steps of the State Capitol honored our city’s history of non-violent social change," Cooper posted on Twitter. "First responders will maintain a presence to protect residents and property." There will be no citywide curfew tonight in Nashville. Yesterday’s peaceful demonstration on the steps of the State Capitol honored our city’s history of non-violent social change. First responders will maintain a presence to protect residents and property. — Mayor John Cooper (@JohnCooper4Nash) June 2, 2020 On Sunday, a day after a peaceful but angry protest spilled onto the street in Clarksville, Mayor Joe Pitts said he felt a duty to listen after meeting with protesters. Here are list of several of those slated locally today: Clarksville 9 a.m. A Non-Violent Protest for Justice at the Montgomery County Courthouse at 2 Millenium Plaza. Organized by Clarksville CORR (a community-action group). A crowd of around 100 gathered in front of the Montgomery County Courthouse to protest police brutality Tuesday, June 2, 2020 (Photo: Henry Taylor / Leaf Chronicle) Spring Hill Noon A Black Lives Matter assembly will begin at 12 p.m. at the Walgreen’s at 4932 Main St. The local event organizer said the assembly will be one of unifying the community and any violent actions will not be tolerated. The assembly on Main St at Campbell Station Pkwy. has concluded. There were no incidents to report. — Spring Hill Police (@SHPDTN) June 2, 2020 Franklin, Clarksville and Nashville 6 p.m. A Franklin prayer vigil at First Missionary Baptist Church at 113 Natchez Street. The event is called Jesus and Justice. A Franklin prayer vigil at First Missionary Baptist Church at 113 Natchez Street. The event is called Jesus and Justice. 6 p.m. A Clarksville March Against Police Brutality that starts at the Fortera Stadium on Henry Street. Protesters plan to march along 8th Street, College Street, 1st Street and then Commerce Street, then end at the city courthouse. A Clarksville March Against Police Brutality that starts at the Fortera Stadium on Henry Street. Protesters plan to march along 8th Street, College Street, 1st Street and then Commerce Street, then end at the city courthouse. 6 p.m. Mayor John Cooper is slated to join community faith leaders for a vigil to encourage peace and unity. The event will take place on the front lawn of the Historic Metro Courthouse until 6:25 p.m. Check back for updates. Reach Natalie Neysa Alund at nalund@tennessean.com and follow her on Twitter @nataliealund. Read or Share this story: https://www.tennessean.com/story/news/local/2020/06/02/black-lives-matter-protests-tennessee-spring-hill-clarksville/5316911002/

title: Rutherford County Jail reports rise of COVID-19 cases involving 21 inmates, 3 employees
text: CLOSE Murfreesboro police officers speak with demonstrators before a march on June 1, 2020, to protest the arrest of MTSU student Christian Fouche during protests the day prior. Murfreesboro Daily News Journal Mayor McFarland speaks on coronavirus and protest Story Highlights Sheriff's deputies encountered protesters who marched to Sheriff's Office and jail Monday. Murfreesboro Mayor Shane McFarland praises officers' response to protests. Jail reported May 20 having kitchen contract worker and inmate testing positive for coronavirus. Coronavirus cases at jail rose to seven inmates by May 26. Three Rutherford County Jail employees have tested positive for the coronavirus, and inmate infections tripled to 21 within a week, a spokeswoman confirmed Tuesday. "The employees are quarantined at home," spokeswoman Lisa Marchesoni said. "The inmates are being quarantined in a separate area away from other inmates." The rise in cases has occurred at a time when deputies are encountering protesters upset about the death of George Floyd in Minneapolis. The protests include a peaceful group that marched Monday to the grounds of the Rutherford County Sheriff's Office and jail at 940 New Salem Highway. Buy Photo Marcher Timothy Russell gets a hug from Rutherford County Sheriff’s Deputy Michael Hoffer at a protest related to the arrest of Christian Fouche, who was arrested after Sunday's vigil in memory of George Floyd in downtown Murfreesboro. Fouche was released Monday. (Photo: HELEN COMER/DNJ) Marchesoni reported May 26 that the jail had seven inmates test positive for the coronavirus. No employees at that time tested positive. Prior to the May 26 cases, Marchesoni reported May 20 that a jail kitchen contract worker tested positive for the coronavirus after being admitted to Vanderbilt University Medical Center in Nashville. The worker has recovered. An inmate who worked in the kitchen also tested positive and is one of the 21 cases involving only male inmates. "It still appears the virus spread from the same source," Marchesoni said, adding that the jail has 679 inmates. "Everyone has been tested. None of the women inmates tested positive for COVID-19." Mayor McFarland speaks on virus Because the sheriff's office must comply with Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act of 1996 regulations, "we cannot release the names of the employees or contract employee," who tested positive, Marchesoni said. The medical staff at the jail routinely screens inmates before they are booked. All inmates being booked into the jail are being quarantined for 14 days, Marchesoni said in a May 6 email to The Daily News Journal. The rise in jail cases comes when Rutherford County had 1,243 coronavirus cases and 23 deaths as of Monday, according to the Tennessee Department of Health. The county also had 11,861 negative tests and 512 people recovered from the coronavirus, Murfreesboro Mayor Shane McFarland told listeners on a Monday night TV broadcast. "Our prayers are with the families who have lost loved ones during this pandemic," McFarland said. The county had spikes in cases in early and late May, but most days have shown a flat trend in increases, McFarland said. "The numbers that we see are still trending downward," and "are headed in the right direction," the mayor said. McFarland also talked about how soccer and baseball leagues have returned to fields. The city's indoor pools are open for structured lap swimming, and Parks and Recreation staff are monitoring conditions to determine when the outdoor Boro Beach pool and playgrounds can reopen, the mayor said. Mayor praises protest response McFarland also talked about the recent protests. He urged people to have more understanding, be kinder and show love a little more. The mayor praised the way officers carried out a plan Sunday to protect the city from violence while honoring the First Amendment rights of protesters. The police had a respectful rapport with the marchers who went around the Square. Officers also showed calm while guarding the entrance to the city's police headquarters on Highland Avenue while protesters insulted them, McFarland said. The mayor said the police use of tear gas at East Main Street and Middle Tennessee Boulevard was necessary because protesters there were blocking the intersection in unsafe ways, including the use of cars, while headed to Forrest Hall at Middle Tennessee State University. The hall's name honors controversial Civil War Confederate Gen. Nathan Bedford Forrest. Police warned people to move out of the intersection before using tear gas, the mayor said. The city also had officers enforce a 6:30 p.m. Sunday night curfew to ensure safety from potential riots that have harmed other cities, McFarland said. SUPPORT OUR WORK: To support award-winning journalism here in Rutherford County, sign up for a digital subscription to DNJ.com. Reach Scott Broden at sbroden@dnj.com or 615-278-5158, and on Twitter @ScottBroden. Read or Share this story: https://www.dnj.com/story/news/2020/06/02/rutherford-county-jail-reports-rise-of-covid-19-cases-involving-21-inmates-3-employees/5316653002/

title: Bishop ‘outraged’ after President Trump poses with Bible in front of St. John’s Church
text: After threatening to use the U.S. military in American cities to put down unrest over the death of George Floyd, President Trump posed for cameras holding a Bible in front of St. John’s Episcopal Church – a moment that left the Right Rev. Mariann Budde “outraged.” Budde, the Episcopal bishop of Washington D.C., spoke with CNN shortly after the photo-op, saying, “Let me be clear, the president just used a Bible, the most sacred text of the Judeo-Christian tradition, and one of the churches of my diocese, without permission, as a backdrop for a message antithetical to the teachings of Jesus.” President Trump had just addressed the nation, calling himself “your president of law and order” and vowing to “dominate the streets.” Video showed officers in protective gear forcibly removing a large crowd of peaceful demonstrators from the area between the White House and the church. “(Trump) sanctioned the use of tear gas by police officers in riot gear to clear the church yard,” Budde said. “I am outraged. The president did not pray when he came to St. John’s, nor … did he acknowledge the agony of our country right now.” Trump, flanked by members of his administration, held the Bible before cameras as he posed in front of the boarded-up church across from the White House. Budde said Trump failed in particular to address the suffering of “the people of color in our nation, who wonder if anyone ever – anyone in public power will ever acknowledge their sacred words – and who are rightfully demanding an end to 400 years of systemic racism and supremacy in our country.”

title: US cities erupt in more violence amid threats from Trump
text: American cities erupted in violence and destruction in a seventh straight night of unrest, with several police officers shot or run over, amid boasts and threats from President Donald Trump to send in troops to "dominate the streets." WASHINGTON — American cities erupted in violence and destruction in a seventh straight night of unrest, with several police officers shot or run over, amid boasts and threats from President Donald Trump to send in troops to "dominate the streets." In New York, nonviolent protests Monday night were punctuated by people smashing shop windows near Rockefeller Center and breaching the doors of Macy's flagship store on 34th Street, littering the pavement with broken glass. An SUV plowed into a group of officers at a demonstration in Buffalo, injuring three, including a state trooper who suffered a broken leg and a shattered pelvis. Demonstrations also broke out in such places as Philadelphia, where hundreds of protesters spilled onto a highway in the heart of the city; Atlanta, where police fired tear gas at demonstrators; and Nashville, where more than 60 National Guard members put down their riot shields at the request of peaceful protesters who had gathered in front of Tennessee's Capitol to honor George Floyd. Bystander Sean Jones, who watched as people ransacked luxury stores in New York over the weekend, said: "People are doing this so next time, before they think about trying to kill another black person, they're going to be like, 'Damn, we don't want them out here doing this ... again.'" The unrest in Minneapolis appeared to stabilize on the same day Floyd's brother made an impassioned plea for peace at the spot where a white police officer, Derek Chauvin, put his knee on the handcuffed black man's neck until he stopped breathing last week. Chauvin has been charged with murder. Minnesota Attorney General Keith Ellison said Tuesday that prosecutors were working as fast as they can to determine if the three other officers at the scene should be charged, too. All four have been fired. The death toll from the unrest rose to at least nine, including two people killed in a Chicago suburb. More than 5,600 people nationwide have been arrested over the past week for such offenses as stealing, blocking highways and breaking curfew, according to a count by The Associated Press. Cities struggled to keep police in line and avoid instances of excessive force. The police chief in Louisville, Kentucky, was fired after a beloved restaurant owner was killed by police and National Guard members enforcing a curfew. In Richmond, Virginia, the police chief said officers who used tear gas on a group of peaceful protesters would be disciplined. An officer was shot shortly before midnight near the Circus Circus casino in Las Vegas. Police had no immediate word on the officer's condition. Four officers were shot in St. Louis; they were expected to recover. Trump, meanwhile, portrayed himself as a hard-nosed, law-and-order president, with police under federal command using tear gas to clear peaceful demonstrators from a park near the White House so that he could walk to a church and pose with a Bible. Emerging after two days out of public view, he threatened from the White House Rose Garden to deploy "thousands and thousands" of U.S. troops. The photo op at the house of worship known as the Church of the Presidents was condemned by Episcopal Bishop Mariann Edgar Budde. "The president just used a Bible and one of the churches of my diocese as a backdrop for a message antithetical to the teachings of Jesus and everything that our church stands for," she said. A senior White House official said Tuesday that despite Trump's threats, the goal was to pressure governors to deploy National Guard units. The president was not rushing to use the Insurrection Act to send in the military, according to the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. For nearly a week since Floyd's death, largely peaceful protests by day have turned to chaos at night. "We have been sitting on a powder keg for some time and it has burst," Philadelphia Police Commissioner Danielle Outlaw said. Trump warned that if governors don't deploy the National Guard in sufficient numbers to "dominate the streets," the U.S. military will step in to "quickly solve the problem for them." "We have the greatest country in the world," the president declared. "We're going to keep it safe." As Trump spoke, tear gas canisters could be heard exploding. A military deployment by Trump to U.S. states would mark a stunning federal intervention rarely seen in modern American history. It drew comparisons to 1968, when Richard Nixon ran as the law-and-order candidate in the aftermath of riots following the assassination of the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. Trump made little effort to address the grievances of black Americans and others outraged by Floyd's death and the scourge of police brutality, undermining what his reelection campaign had hoped would be increased appeal to African American voters. Federal law allows presidents to dispatch the military into states to suppress an insurrection or if a state is defying federal law, legal experts said. But officials in New York and other states asserted that the president does not have a unilateral right to send in troops against the will of local governments.

title: Stocks open higher as investors hope for economic recovery
text: U.S. stock indexes are moving higher in early trading Tuesday, following broad gains in global markets as investors hope that the gradual lifting of coronavirus lockdown mandates will put economies ravaged by the outbreak on the path to recovery. U.S. stock indexes are moving higher in early trading Tuesday, following broad gains in global markets as investors hope that the gradual lifting of coronavirus lockdown mandates will put economies ravaged by the outbreak on the path to recovery. The S&P 500 was up 0.4%, adding to gains from the day before. Financial, industrial and other stocks that would stand to benefit the most from a growing economy moved higher. Energy companies also rose as the price of crude oil headed higher. Bond yields were mostly higher, another sign of ebbing pessimism among investors. The modest gains have the S&P 500 on track for a three-day winning streak, extending the benchmark index's remarkable two-month rally off a steep skid in February and March as broad swaths of the U.S. economy ground to a halt due to the coronavirus pandemic. So far, Wall Street's momentum has not been derailed by the wave of daily unrest across the U.S. that began last week in Minneapolis as a protest over police brutality. Cities across the country have been rocked by violence and destruction for seven days in a row, spurring threats from the White House to send troops in to put down the unrest. The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 189 points, or 0.7%, to 25,668. The Nasdaq composite was up 0.2%. Smaller company stocks had some of the biggest gains in the early going. The Russell 2000 index was up 0.8%. NASA astronauts launched into space by SpaceX on Saturday rang the opening bell from the International Space Station early Tuesday to kick off trading on the New York Stock Exchange. Stocks have now recouped most of their losses after the initial economic fallout from the coronavirus knocked the market into a breathtaking 34% skid in February and March. The S&P 500 is now down just under 10% from its all-time high in February. Investors are hoping that the worst of the recession has already passed, or will soon, as governments around the country and around the world slowly lift restrictions meant to corral the outbreak. In Europe, France's CAC 40 jumped 2.1% Tuesday as the country opened restaurants, cafes, parks and beaches and launched a contract tracing app to help keep tabs on new contagions. Germany's DAX, which had been closed Monday, caught up with previous global markets' gains and surged 3.7%. Britain's FTSE 100 added 0.9%. Markets in Asia closed broadly higher. While more countries and sectors are reopening, activity is expected to remain subdued as social distancing rules complicate plans to get back to business. And fears persist about a possible resurgence in coronavirus outbreaks in some countries. There were 34 new confirmed cases in Tokyo on Tuesday, seeming to reaffirm growing risks as people begin to mingle more in crowded commuter trains with the reopenings of more offices, schools, restaurants and stores. The daily numbers had dropped below 20 recently. Bond yields were mostly higher. The yield on the 10-year Treasury rose to 0.67% from 0.66% late Monday. Oil prices rose. Benchmark U.S. crude oil for July delivery was up 1.9% to $36.10 a barrel. Brent crude oil for August delivery rose 2% to $39.09 a barrel.

title: Governors Push Back On Trump's Threat To Deploy Federal Troops To Quell Unrest
text: Updated at 10:33 a.m. ET President Trump, in a conference call Monday with the nation's governors, threatened to deploy the U.S. military to restore order unless states hit by days of unrest "put down" violent demonstrations, urging leaders to "dominate" lawbreakers or risk looking like "a bunch of jerks." The upbraiding from the White House didn't sit well with many governors, who have been busy responding to clashes between protesters and law enforcement in dozens of U.S. cities sparked by the death a week ago of George Floyd after a Minneapolis police officer knelt on his neck. Trump took a tough line with the governors, saying he was putting Attorney General William Barr in charge of the federal law enforcement response. The president said the White House was "strongly looking for arrests." "You have to arrest people and you have to try people. And they have to go to jail for long periods of time," the president said. "If people are running amok, you have to dominate. If you aren't dominating, you're wasting your time," he said. "They're going to run over you; you're going to look like a bunch of jerks." "It's a movement. If you don't put it down, it will get worse and worse," Trump said. "The only time it's successful is when you're weak and most of you are weak." The call followed yet another night of unrest Sunday over the May 25 death of Floyd and came on the same day that the president in a Rose Garden address urged governors deploy National Guard troops to quell the unrest. "If a city or state refuses to take the actions that are necessary to defend the life and property of their residents, then I will deploy the United States military and quickly solve the problem for them," he said. In the nation's capital, where U.S. Secret Service uniformed officers, military police and other law enforcement on Monday fired tear gas on peaceful protesters outside of the White House, Trump said he was already "dispatching thousands and thousands of heavily armed soldiers, military personnel and law enforcement officers to stop the rioting, looting, vandalism, assaults and the wanton destruction of property." While some governors, such as South Carolina's Henry McMaster, a Republican, praised Trump's calls for a crackdown, others took umbrage at the president's combative tone and questioned his authority to unilaterally deploy federal troops to the states. During the conference call, Illinois Gov. J.B. Pritzker, a Democrat, warned the president that the "rhetoric coming out of the White House is making it worse," to which Trump snapped back, "I don't like your rhetoric that much either." "I had to speak up, and I told him that his rhetoric is inflaming matters, that it's making things worse, and that we need to call for police reform," Pritzker told NPR's Morning Edition on Tuesday. "We need to call for calm, that that's what the president should do and we need national leadership in this regard." "He unfortunately — you know," the governor added, "he reacted badly." Pritzker also said that what Trump's suggesting is "illegal." "The governor of a state has to ask for federal help. I don't know any governor that intends to do that," he said. "And secondly, you know, you can hear in his rhetoric that he is simply trying to make himself sound like a strong man — almost like a dictator, as if he's going to be responsible for bringing order all the way." In Michigan, where police and protesters have skirmished in Grand Rapids despite many demonstrations remaining peaceful, Gov. Gretchen Whitmer, a Democrat, called the president's remarks "dangerous" and said they should be "gravely concerning to all Americans." The president's comments, she said, "send a clear signal that this administration is determined to sow the seeds of hatred and division, which I fear will only lead to more violence and destruction." "We must reject this way of thinking. This is a moment that calls for empathy, humanity, and unity," Whitmer said in a statement. "This is one of the most challenging periods in our nation's history, but as Americans, we must remember our enemy is racial injustice, not one another." The Republican governor of Massachusetts, Charlie Baker, said he wasn't surprised by the president's "incendiary words." "At so many times during these last several weeks, when the country needed compassion and leadership the most, it simply was nowhere to be found," he said following the phone call with Trump. "Instead, we got bitterness, combativeness and self-interest. That's not what we need in Boston, it's not what we need right now in Massachusetts," he said as his voice cracked with emotion, "and it's definitely not what we need across this great country of ours either." Washington Gov. Jay Inslee, a Democrat, called the president's remarks the "rantings of an insecure man trying to look strong after building his entire political career on racism." On the subject of the deploying of federal troops, Democratic New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo told CNN that he would respond to such an offer by saying, "Thank you, but no thank you." "He wants to make this about looting because he doesn't want to talk about the killing of Mr. Floyd," Cuomo said. "[He] doesn't want to really talk about racism and discrimination." Kentucky Democratic Gov. Andy Beshear was reportedly not on the call with the president. Beshear was instead talking with the mother of Breonna Taylor, a 26-year-old African American resident of Louisville who was killed in March by police executing a no-knock warrant. The president did praise one Democratic governor for his response to the unrest — Minnesota's Tim Walz, who fully mobilized National Guard troops on Saturday to supplement law enforcement. But at another point in the call, Trump called Minnesota "a laughingstock all over the world." Walz said Monday that he responded by saying: "No one's laughing here. We're in pain. We're crying. We saw a man lose his life in front of them and our challenge is that this is about social trust, social compacts and reestablishing faith in the people who are there to serve them." NPR's Colin Dwyer contributed to this report.

title: Confederate monuments targeted by protests come down
text: The base of a massive Confederate monument in Alabama's largest city was all that remained Tuesday after crews dismantled the towering obelisk and trucked it away in pieces. Other symbols came down elsewhere, leaving an empty pedestal and a bare flagpole. BIRMINGHAM, Ala. — The base of a massive Confederate monument in Alabama's largest city was all that remained Tuesday after crews dismantled the towering obelisk and trucked it away in pieces. Other symbols came down elsewhere, leaving an empty pedestal and a bare flagpole. Workers hired by the city of Birmingham began removing the top portion of the 115-year-old monument from Linn Park late Monday. By daybreak, the pedestal was the only thing left, covered with graffiti and pock marks from protests against police brutality. Sarah Collins Rudolph, whose sister Addie Mae Collins died in a racist church bombing that killed three other black girls in the city in 1963, came to see the remains. She lowered a protective face mask to take in the sight. "I'm glad it's been removed because it has been so long. It's a hate monument," said Rudolph. She was seriously injured in the blast at 16th Street Baptist Church, and testified against Ku Klux Klansmen who were convicted in the killings. Confederate symbols across the South have been targeted for vandalism during demonstrations sparked by the death in police custody of George Floyd in Minneapolis. Now even some of their longtime defenders have decided to remove them. In Alexandria, Virginia, it was the United Daughters of the Confederacy that took action early Tuesday, removing the statue of a soldier gazing south from Old Town since 1889. And outside Tampa, Florida, a Sons of Confederate Veterans chapter lowered a huge Confederate battle flag that has long been flown in view of two interstate highways. Birmingham finally took action about a day after protesters tried to remove the monument themselves, during one of the many nationwide protests sparked by the death of George Floyd in Minneapolis police custody. Live video from overnight showed a flatbed truck hauling off the stone pieces in the early morning hours. It's unclear where they were being taken. Crews were expected to return later Tuesday to finish the job, a city official said. The monument had been the subject of a protracted court battle between the city and state. Alabama authorities said Birmingham would face a $25,000 assessment for violating a state law that bans the removal of such monuments. Mayor Randall Woodfin said the fine would be much more affordable than the cost of continued unrest in the city. Work to remove the monument began on Monday, which happened to be Alabama's holiday honoring Confederate President Jefferson Davis, who was sworn in on the steps of the state Capitol in Montgomery. There, on the same day, someone knocked over a statue of Confederate Gen. Robert E. Lee outside a mostly black high school named for him, news outlets reported. In Alexandria, a city spokesman said the United Daughters of the Confederacy informed the city on Monday that it would remove the statue, and the city's only role was to provide traffic support. By morning, the pedestal was all that was left. City officials were not told where the statue was taken. Titled "Appomattox," it depicts a solitary Confederate soldier, his head bowed slightly. In 1890, a state law was passed barring local officials from ever removing it. That law was repealed earlier this year. Alexandria Mayor Justin Wilson tweeted photos of the removal on Tuesday, saying "Alexandria, like all great cities, is constantly changing and evolving."

title: Confederate monuments toppled, burned as protests over George Floyd's death continue
text: Protests in response to the death of George Floyd – a handcuffed black man who was asphyxiated as a white police officer knelt on his neck – once again spotlighted frustration over the presence of Confederate monuments in some cities as anger over police brutality and racism intensified over the last week. A statue of Confederate Gen. Robert E. Lee was toppled from its pedestal in front of the namesake high school in Montgomery, Alabama, Monday night. Cheers went up among a small crowd gathered to watch the fallen stone general as cars circled the area and honked. As the statue was driven away, the crowd sang a brief, "Hey, he-ey, goodbye." The statue was overturned on a state holiday commemorating Jefferson Davis' birthday. It is one of three Alabama holidays celebrating the Confederacy, a government that rested on the principle of white supremacy. Montgomery Police acknowledged Monday night that people had been arrested in the incident, though didn't offer any other details. "The statue was damaged and there are suspects in custody. Charges are pending," Montgomery Police Captain Saba Coleman said. The Montgomery Public School district announced Tuesday that the statute had been moved to storage. Any decisions about the statue or the name of the school will be left to the school board, said City spokesman Griffith Waller. Monuments in several other Southern cities were the site of protests over the weekend. A statue outside the Tennessee State Capitol of Edward Carmack, a controversial former lawmaker and newspaper publisher who espoused racist views, was torn down Saturday. Carmack was known for writing editorials attacking fellow Tennessee journalist Ida B. Wells' writings in support of the civil rights movement, including encouraging retaliation against her, resulting in the burning of her Memphis newspaper office. The Robert E. Lee memorial on Monument Avenue in Richmond, Virginia, was covered in graffiti Saturday night, as was the Stonewall Jackson statute. The headquarters of the United Daughters of the Confederacy was similarly tagged and set on fire, according to the Richmond Times-Dispatch. The Confederate Defenders statute along the Battery in Charleston, South Carolina, was spray-painted. A peaceful protest there the next morning was dispersed, the Post and Courier reported. The brass cast of Charles Linn in Birmingham, Alabama, was left lying on the ground Sunday night, dismantled from its base. Then Monday night, crews with heavy equipment attached straps to the 50-foot-tall obelisk of the Confederate Soldiers and Sailors monument in the same park, working at the direction of Birmingham Mayor Randall Woodfin to remove the 115-year-old stone memorial. The monument had been at the center of a fight between the city and the Alabama Attorney General's Office, according to AL.com. The city lost a legal battle to have it removed. And it wasn't just monuments. In Fayetteville, North Carolina, a crowd set fire to the Market House, a National Historic Landmark constructed in 1832 on the site of the old statehouse. It was used as a town hall and marketplace and was the site of the sale of slaves. In recent years, the presence of Confederate monuments has come under intense scrutiny.
